    4377             :                  * Make sure it's still an appropriate lock, else start over.
    4378             :                  * Also, if it wasn't updated before we released the lock, but

    4465             :          * not about recording the lock in Xmax (which will be done regardless

    4491             :          * required to sleep, get out to raise an error instead.
    4492             :          *
    4493             :          * By here, we either have already acquired the buffer exclusive lock,
    4494             :          * or we must wait for the locking transaction or multixact; so below

    4505             :              * Acquire tuple lock to establish our priority for the tuple, or

    4508             :              * but not if we already have a weaker lock on the tuple.
    4509             :              *

    4767      163386 :     MarkBufferDirty(*buffer);
    4768             : 
    4769             :     /*
    4770             :      * XLOG stuff.  You might think that we don't need an XLOG record because
    4771             :      * there is no state change worth restoring after a crash.  You would be
    4772             :      * wrong however: we have just written either a TransactionId or a
    4773             :      * MultiXactId that may never have been seen on disk before, and we need
    4774             :      * to make sure that there are XLOG entries covering those ID numbers.
    4775             :      * Else the same IDs might be re-used after a crash, which would be
    4776             :      * disastrous if this page made it to disk before the crash.  Essentially
    4777             :      * we have to enforce the WAL log-before-data rule even in this case.
    4778             :      * (Also, in a PITR log-shipping or 2PC environment, we have to have XLOG
    4779             :      * entries for everything anyway.)
    4780             :      */
    4781      163386 :     if (RelationNeedsWAL(relation))

    4815             :      * Don't update the visibility map here. Locking a tuple doesn't change
    4816             :      * visibility info.
    4817             :      */
    4818             : 
    4819             :     /*
    4820             :      * Now that we have successfully marked the tuple as locked, we can
    4821             :      * release the lmgr tuple lock, if we had it.
    4822             :      */
    4823      164704 :     if (have_tuple_lock)
    4824         274 :         UnlockTupleTuplock(relation, tid, mode);
    4825             : 
    4826      164704 :     return result;
    4827             : }
    4828             : 
    4829             : /*
    4830             :  * Acquire heavyweight lock on the given tuple, in preparation for acquiring
    4831             :  * its normal, Xmax-based tuple lock.
    4832             :  *
    4833             :  * have_tuple_lock is an input and output parameter: on input, it indicates
    4834             :  * whether the lock has previously been acquired (and this function does
    4835             :  * nothing in that case).  If this function returns success, have_tuple_lock
    4836             :  * has been flipped to true.
    4837             :  *
    4838             :  * Returns false if it was unable to obtain the lock; this can only happen if
    4839             :  * wait_policy is Skip.
    4840             :  */
    4841             : static bool
    4842         508 : heap_acquire_tuplock(Relation relation, ItemPointer tid, LockTupleMode mode,
    4843             :                      LockWaitPolicy wait_policy, bool *have_tuple_lock)
    4844             : {
    4845         508 :     if (*have_tuple_lock)
    4846          18 :         return true;
    4847             : 
    4848         490 :     switch (wait_policy)
    4849             :     {
    4850         408 :         case LockWaitBlock:
    4851         408 :             LockTupleTuplock(relation, tid, mode);
    4852         408 :             break;
    4853             : 
    4854          68 :         case LockWaitSkip:
    4855          68 :             if (!ConditionalLockTupleTuplock(relation, tid, mode))
    4856           2 :                 return false;
    4857          66 :             break;
    4858             : 
    4859          14 :         case LockWaitError:
    4860          14 :             if (!ConditionalLockTupleTuplock(relation, tid, mode))
    4861           2 :                 ereport(ERROR,
    4862             :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_LOCK_NOT_AVAILABLE),

    4864             :                                 RelationGetRelationName(relation))));
    4865          12 :             break;
    4866             :     }
    4867         486 :     *have_tuple_lock = true;
    4868             : 
    4869         486 :     return true;
    4870             : }
    4871             : 
    4872             : /*
    4873             :  * Given an original set of Xmax and infomask, and a transaction (identified by
    4874             :  * add_to_xmax) acquiring a new lock of some mode, compute the new Xmax and
    4875             :  * corresponding infomasks to use on the tuple.
    4876             :  *
    4877             :  * Note that this might have side effects such as creating a new MultiXactId.
    4878             :  *
    4879             :  * Most callers will have called HeapTupleSatisfiesUpdate before this function;
    4880             :  * that will have set the HEAP_XMAX_INVALID bit if the xmax was a MultiXactId
    4881             :  * but it was not running anymore. There is a race condition, which is that the
    4882             :  * MultiXactId may have finished since then, but that uncommon case is handled
    4883             :  * either here, or within MultiXactIdExpand.
    4884             :  *
    4885             :  * There is a similar race condition possible when the old xmax was a regular
    4886             :  * TransactionId.  We test TransactionIdIsInProgress again just to narrow the
    4887             :  * window, but it's still possible to end up creating an unnecessary
    4888             :  * MultiXactId.  Fortunately this is harmless.
    4889             :  */

    5155             : 
    5156             : /*
    5157             :  * Subroutine for heap_lock_updated_tuple_rec.
    5158             :  *
    5159             :  * Given a hypothetical multixact status held by the transaction identified
    5160             :  * with the given xid, does the current transaction need to wait, fail, or can
    5161             :  * it continue if it wanted to acquire a lock of the given mode?  "needwait"
    5162             :  * is set to true if waiting is necessary; if it can continue, then TM_Ok is
    5163             :  * returned.  If the lock is already held by the current transaction, return
    5164             :  * TM_SelfModified.  In case of a conflict with another transaction, a
    5165             :  * different HeapTupleSatisfiesUpdate return code is returned.
    5166             :  *
    5167             :  * The held status is said to be hypothetical because it might correspond to a
    5168             :  * lock held by a single Xid, i.e. not a real MultiXactId; we express it this
    5169             :  * way for simplicity of API.
    5170             :  */
    5171             : static TM_Result
    5172          64 : test_lockmode_for_conflict(MultiXactStatus status, TransactionId xid,
    5173             :                            LockTupleMode mode, HeapTuple tup,
    5174             :                            bool *needwait)
    5175             : {
    5176             :     MultiXactStatus wantedstatus;
    5177             : 
    5178          64 :     *needwait = false;
    5179          64 :     wantedstatus = get_mxact_status_for_lock(mode, false);
    5180             : 
    5181             :     /*
    5182             :      * Note: we *must* check TransactionIdIsInProgress before
    5183             :      * TransactionIdDidAbort/Commit; see comment at top of heapam_visibility.c
    5184             :      * for an explanation.
    5185             :      */
    5186          64 :     if (TransactionIdIsCurrentTransactionId(xid))
    5187             :     {
    5188             :         /*
    5189             :          * The tuple has already been locked by our own transaction.  This is
    5190             :          * very rare but can happen if multiple transactions are trying to
    5191             :          * lock an ancient version of the same tuple.
    5192             :          */
    5193           0 :         return TM_SelfModified;
    5194             :     }
    5195          64 :     else if (TransactionIdIsInProgress(xid))
    5196             :     {
    5197             :         /*
    5198             :          * If the locking transaction is running, what we do depends on
    5199             :          * whether the lock modes conflict: if they do, then we must wait for
    5200             :          * it to finish; otherwise we can fall through to lock this tuple
    5201             :          * version without waiting.
    5202             :          */
    5203          32 :         if (DoLockModesConflict(LOCKMODE_from_mxstatus(status),
    5204          32 :                                 LOCKMODE_from_mxstatus(wantedstatus)))
    5205             :         {
    5206          16 :             *needwait = true;
    5207             :         }
    5208             : 
    5209             :         /*
    5210             :          * If we set needwait above, then this value doesn't matter;
    5211             :          * otherwise, this value signals to caller that it's okay to proceed.
    5212             :          */
    5213          32 :         return TM_Ok;
    5214             :     }
    5215          32 :     else if (TransactionIdDidAbort(xid))
    5216           6 :         return TM_Ok;

    5218             :     {
    5219             :         /*
    5220             :          * The other transaction committed.  If it was only a locker, then the
    5221             :          * lock is completely gone now and we can return success; but if it
    5222             :          * was an update, then what we do depends on whether the two lock
    5223             :          * modes conflict.  If they conflict, then we must report error to
    5224             :          * caller. But if they don't, we can fall through to allow the current
    5225             :          * transaction to lock the tuple.
    5226             :          *
    5227             :          * Note: the reason we worry about ISUPDATE here is because as soon as
    5228             :          * a transaction ends, all its locks are gone and meaningless, and
    5229             :          * thus we can ignore them; whereas its updates persist.  In the
    5230             :          * TransactionIdIsInProgress case, above, we don't need to check
    5231             :          * because we know the lock is still "alive" and thus a conflict needs
    5232             :          * always be checked.
    5233             :          */
    5234          26 :         if (!ISUPDATE_from_mxstatus(status))
    5235           8 :             return TM_Ok;
    5236             : 
    5237          18 :         if (DoLockModesConflict(LOCKMODE_from_mxstatus(status),

    5243             :             else
    5244           4 :                 return TM_Deleted;
    5245             :         }
    5246             : 
    5247           2 :         return TM_Ok;
    5248             :     }
    5249             : 
    5250             :     /* Not in progress, not aborted, not committed -- must have crashed */
    5251           0 :     return TM_Ok;
    5252             : }
    5253             : 
    5254             : 
    5255             : /*
    5256             :  * Recursive part of heap_lock_updated_tuple
    5257             :  *
    5258             :  * Fetch the tuple pointed to by tid in rel, and mark it as locked by the given
    5259             :  * xid with the given mode; if this tuple is updated, recurse to lock the new
    5260             :  * version as well.
    5261             :  */
    5262             : static TM_Result
    5263         160 : heap_lock_updated_tuple_rec(Relation rel, ItemPointer tid, TransactionId xid,
    5264             :                             LockTupleMode mode)
    5265             : {
    5266             :     TM_Result   result;
    5267             :     ItemPointerData tupid;
    5268             :     HeapTupleData mytup;
    5269             :     Buffer      buf;
    5270             :     uint16      new_infomask,
    5271             :                 new_infomask2,

    5273             :                 old_infomask2;
    5274             :     TransactionId xmax,
    5275             :                 new_xmax;
    5276         160 :     TransactionId priorXmax = InvalidTransactionId;
    5277         160 :     bool        cleared_all_frozen = false;
    5278             :     bool        pinned_desired_page;
    5279         160 :     Buffer      vmbuffer = InvalidBuffer;
    5280             :     BlockNumber block;
    5281             : 
    5282         160 :     ItemPointerCopy(tid, &tupid);
    5283             : 
    5284             :     for (;;)
    5285             :     {
    5286         166 :         new_infomask = 0;
    5287         166 :         new_xmax = InvalidTransactionId;
    5288         166 :         block = ItemPointerGetBlockNumber(&tupid);
    5289         166 :         ItemPointerCopy(&tupid, &(mytup.t_self));
    5290             : 
    5291         166 :         if (!heap_fetch(rel, SnapshotAny, &mytup, &buf, false))
    5292             :         {
    5293             :             /*
    5294             :              * if we fail to find the updated version of the tuple, it's
    5295             :              * because it was vacuumed/pruned away after its creator
    5296             :              * transaction aborted.  So behave as if we got to the end of the
    5297             :              * chain, and there's no further tuple to lock: return success to
    5298             :              * caller.
    5299             :              */
    5300           0 :             result = TM_Ok;
    5301           0 :             goto out_unlocked;
    5302             :         }
    5303             : 
    5304         166 : l4:

    5307             :         /*
    5308             :          * Before locking the buffer, pin the visibility map page if it

    5311             :          * to recheck after we have the lock.

    5584             : 
    5585             : /*
    5586             :  * heap_lock_updated_tuple
    5587             :  *      Follow update chain when locking an updated tuple, acquiring locks (row
    5588             :  *      marks) on the updated versions.
    5589             :  *
    5590             :  * The initial tuple is assumed to be already locked.
    5591             :  *
    5592             :  * This function doesn't check visibility, it just unconditionally marks the
    5593             :  * tuple(s) as locked.  If any tuple in the updated chain is being deleted
    5594             :  * concurrently (or updated with the key being modified), sleep until the
    5595             :  * transaction doing it is finished.
    5596             :  *
    5597             :  * Note that we don't acquire heavyweight tuple locks on the tuples we walk
    5598             :  * when we have to wait for other transactions to release them, as opposed to
    5599             :  * what heap_lock_tuple does.  The reason is that having more than one
    5600             :  * transaction walking the chain is probably uncommon enough that risk of
    5601             :  * starvation is not likely: one of the preconditions for being here is that
    5602             :  * the snapshot in use predates the update that created this tuple (because we
    5603             :  * started at an earlier version of the tuple), but at the same time such a
    5604             :  * transaction cannot be using repeatable read or serializable isolation
    5605             :  * levels, because that would lead to a serializability failure.
    5606             :  */
    5607             : static TM_Result
    5608         176 : heap_lock_updated_tuple(Relation rel, HeapTuple tuple, ItemPointer ctid,
    5609             :                         TransactionId xid, LockTupleMode mode)
    5610             : {
    5611             :     /*
    5612             :      * If the tuple has not been updated, or has moved into another partition
    5613             :      * (effectively a delete) stop here.
    5614             :      */
    5615         176 :     if (!HeapTupleHeaderIndicatesMovedPartitions(tuple->t_data) &&
    5616         172 :         !ItemPointerEquals(&tuple->t_self, ctid))
    5617             :     {
    5618             :         /*
    5619             :          * If this is the first possibly-multixact-able operation in the
    5620             :          * current transaction, set my per-backend OldestMemberMXactId
    5621             :          * setting. We can be certain that the transaction will never become a
    5622             :          * member of any older MultiXactIds than that.  (We have to do this
    5623             :          * even if we end up just using our own TransactionId below, since
    5624             :          * some other backend could incorporate our XID into a MultiXact
    5625             :          * immediately afterwards.)
    5626             :          */
    5627         160 :         MultiXactIdSetOldestMember();
    5628             : 
    5629         160 :         return heap_lock_updated_tuple_rec(rel, ctid, xid, mode);
    5630             :     }
    5631             : 
    5632             :     /* nothing to lock */
    5633          16 :     return TM_Ok;
    5634             : }
    5635             : 
    5636             : /*
    5637             :  *  heap_finish_speculative - mark speculative insertion as successful
    5638             :  *
    5639             :  * To successfully finish a speculative insertion we have to clear speculative
    5640             :  * token from tuple.  To do so the t_ctid field, which will contain a
    5641             :  * speculative token value, is modified in place to point to the tuple itself,
    5642             :  * which is characteristic of a newly inserted ordinary tuple.
    5643             :  *
    5644             :  * NB: It is not ok to commit without either finishing or aborting a
    5645             :  * speculative insertion.  We could treat speculative tuples of committed
    5646             :  * transactions implicitly as completed, but then we would have to be prepared
    5647             :  * to deal with speculative tokens on committed tuples.  That wouldn't be
    5648             :  * difficult - no-one looks at the ctid field of a tuple with invalid xmax -
    5649             :  * but clearing the token at completion isn't very expensive either.
    5650             :  * An explicit confirmation WAL record also makes logical decoding simpler.
    5651             :  */
    5652             : void
    5653        4010 : heap_finish_speculative(Relation relation, ItemPointer tid)
    5654             : {
    5655             :     Buffer      buffer;
    5656             :     Page        page;
    5657             :     OffsetNumber offnum;
    5658        4010 :     ItemId      lp = NULL;
    5659             :     HeapTupleHeader htup;
    5660             : 
    5661        4010 :     buffer = ReadBuffer(relation, ItemPointerGetBlockNumber(tid));
    5662        4010 :     LockBuffer(buffer, BUFFER_LOCK_EXCLUSIVE);
    5663        4010 :     page = (Page) BufferGetPage(buffer);
    5664             : 
    5665        4010 :     offnum = ItemPointerGetOffsetNumber(tid);
    5666        4010 :     if (PageGetMaxOffsetNumber(page) >= offnum)
    5667        4010 :         lp = PageGetItemId(page, offnum);
    5668             : 
    5669        4010 :     if (PageGetMaxOffsetNumber(page) < offnum || !ItemIdIsNormal(lp))
    5670           0 :         elog(ERROR, "invalid lp");
    5671             : 
    5672        4010 :     htup = (HeapTupleHeader) PageGetItem(page, lp);
    5673             : 
    5674             :     /* NO EREPORT(ERROR) from here till changes are logged */
    5675        4010 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    5676             : 
    5677        4010 :     Assert(HeapTupleHeaderIsSpeculative(htup));
    5678             : 
    5679        4010 :     MarkBufferDirty(buffer);

    5698        3998 :         XLogSetRecordFlags(XLOG_INCLUDE_ORIGIN);

    5701        3998 :         XLogRegisterBuffer(0, buffer, REGBUF_STANDARD);
    5702             : 
    5703        3998 :         recptr = XLogInsert(RM_HEAP_ID, XLOG_HEAP_CONFIRM);
    5704             : 
    5705        3998 :         PageSetLSN(page, recptr);
    5706             :     }
    5707             : 
    5708        4010 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    5709             : 
    5710        4010 :     UnlockReleaseBuffer(buffer);
    5711        4010 : }
    5712             : 
    5713             : /*
    5714             :  *  heap_abort_speculative - kill a speculatively inserted tuple
    5715             :  *
    5716             :  * Marks a tuple that was speculatively inserted in the same command as dead,
    5717             :  * by setting its xmin as invalid.  That makes it immediately appear as dead
    5718             :  * to all transactions, including our own.  In particular, it makes
    5719             :  * HeapTupleSatisfiesDirty() regard the tuple as dead, so that another backend
    5720             :  * inserting a duplicate key value won't unnecessarily wait for our whole
    5721             :  * transaction to finish (it'll just wait for our speculative insertion to
    5722             :  * finish).
    5723             :  *
    5724             :  * Killing the tuple prevents "unprincipled deadlocks", which are deadlocks
    5725             :  * that arise due to a mutual dependency that is not user visible.  By
    5726             :  * definition, unprincipled deadlocks cannot be prevented by the user
    5727             :  * reordering lock acquisition in client code, because the implementation level
    5728             :  * lock acquisitions are not under the user's direct control.  If speculative
    5729             :  * inserters did not take this precaution, then under high concurrency they
    5730             :  * could deadlock with each other, which would not be acceptable.
    5731             :  *
    5732             :  * This is somewhat redundant with heap_delete, but we prefer to have a
    5733             :  * dedicated routine with stripped down requirements.  Note that this is also
    5734             :  * used to delete the TOAST tuples created during speculative insertion.
    5735             :  *
    5736             :  * This routine does not affect logical decoding as it only looks at
    5737             :  * confirmation records.
    5738             :  */
    5739             : void
    5740          20 : heap_abort_speculative(Relation relation, ItemPointer tid)
    5741             : {
    5742          20 :     TransactionId xid = GetCurrentTransactionId();
    5743             :     ItemId      lp;
    5744             :     HeapTupleData tp;
    5745             :     Page        page;
    5746             :     BlockNumber block;
    5747             :     Buffer      buffer;
    5748             :     TransactionId prune_xid;
    5749             : 
    5750          20 :     Assert(ItemPointerIsValid(tid));
    5751             : 
    5752          20 :     block = ItemPointerGetBlockNumber(tid);
    5753          20 :     buffer = ReadBuffer(relation, block);
    5754          20 :     page = BufferGetPage(buffer);
    5755             : 
    5756          20 :     LockBuffer(buffer, BUFFER_LOCK_EXCLUSIVE);
    5757             : 
    5758             :     /*
    5759             :      * Page can't be all visible, we just inserted into it, and are still
    5760             :      * running.
    5761             :      */
    5762          20 :     Assert(!PageIsAllVisible(page));
    5763             : 
    5764          20 :     lp = PageGetItemId(page, ItemPointerGetOffsetNumber(tid));
    5765          20 :     Assert(ItemIdIsNormal(lp));
    5766             : 
    5767          20 :     tp.t_tableOid = RelationGetRelid(relation);
    5768          20 :     tp.t_data = (HeapTupleHeader) PageGetItem(page, lp);
    5769          20 :     tp.t_len = ItemIdGetLength(lp);
    5770          20 :     tp.t_self = *tid;
    5771             : 
    5772             :     /*
    5773             :      * Sanity check that the tuple really is a speculatively inserted tuple,
    5774             :      * inserted by us.
    5775             :      */
    5776          20 :     if (tp.t_data->t_choice.t_heap.t_xmin != xid)
    5777           0 :         elog(ERROR, "attempted to kill a tuple inserted by another transaction");
    5778          20 :     if (!(IsToastRelation(relation) || HeapTupleHeaderIsSpeculative(tp.t_data)))
    5779           0 :         elog(ERROR, "attempted to kill a non-speculative tuple");
    5780          20 :     Assert(!HeapTupleHeaderIsHeapOnly(tp.t_data));
    5781             : 
    5782             :     /*
    5783             :      * No need to check for serializable conflicts here.  There is never a
    5784             :      * need for a combo CID, either.  No need to extract replica identity, or
    5785             :      * do anything special with infomask bits.
    5786             :      */
    5787             : 
    5788          20 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    5789             : 
    5790             :     /*
    5791             :      * The tuple will become DEAD immediately.  Flag that this page is a
    5792             :      * candidate for pruning by setting xmin to TransactionXmin. While not
    5793             :      * immediately prunable, it is the oldest xid we can cheaply determine
    5794             :      * that's safe against wraparound / being older than the table's
    5795             :      * relfrozenxid.  To defend against the unlikely case of a new relation
    5796             :      * having a newer relfrozenxid than our TransactionXmin, use relfrozenxid
    5797             :      * if so (vacuum can't subsequently move relfrozenxid to beyond
    5798             :      * TransactionXmin, so there's no race here).
    5799             :      */
    5800          20 :     Assert(TransactionIdIsValid(TransactionXmin));
    5801          20 :     if (TransactionIdPrecedes(TransactionXmin, relation->rd_rel->relfrozenxid))
    5802           0 :         prune_xid = relation->rd_rel->relfrozenxid;
    5803             :     else
    5804          20 :         prune_xid = TransactionXmin;
    5805          20 :     PageSetPrunable(page, prune_xid);
    5806             : 
    5807             :     /* store transaction information of xact deleting the tuple */
    5808          20 :     tp.t_data->t_infomask &= ~(HEAP_XMAX_BITS | HEAP_MOVED);
    5809          20 :     tp.t_data->t_infomask2 &= ~HEAP_KEYS_UPDATED;
    5810             : 
    5811             :     /*
    5812             :      * Set the tuple header xmin to InvalidTransactionId.  This makes the
    5813             :      * tuple immediately invisible everyone.  (In particular, to any
    5814             :      * transactions waiting on the speculative token, woken up later.)
    5815             :      */
    5816          20 :     HeapTupleHeaderSetXmin(tp.t_data, InvalidTransactionId);
    5817             : 
    5818             :     /* Clear the speculative insertion token too */
    5819          20 :     tp.t_data->t_ctid = tp.t_self;
    5820             : 
    5821          20 :     MarkBufferDirty(buffer);
    5822             : 
    5823             :     /*
    5824             :      * XLOG stuff
    5825             :      *
    5826             :      * The WAL records generated here match heap_delete().  The same recovery
    5827             :      * routines are used.
    5828             :      */
    5829          20 :     if (RelationNeedsWAL(relation))
    5830             :     {
    5831             :         xl_heap_delete xlrec;
    5832             :         XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    5833             : 
    5834          20 :         xlrec.flags = XLH_DELETE_IS_SUPER;
    5835          40 :         xlrec.infobits_set = compute_infobits(tp.t_data->t_infomask,
    5836          20 :                                               tp.t_data->t_infomask2);
    5837          20 :         xlrec.offnum = ItemPointerGetOffsetNumber(&tp.t_self);
    5838          20 :         xlrec.xmax = xid;
    5839             : 
    5840          20 :         XLogBeginInsert();
    5841          20 :         XLogRegisterData((char *) &xlrec, SizeOfHeapDelete);
    5842          20 :         XLogRegisterBuffer(0, buffer, REGBUF_STANDARD);
    5843             : 
    5844             :         /* No replica identity & replication origin logged */
    5845             : 
    5846          20 :         recptr = XLogInsert(RM_HEAP_ID, XLOG_HEAP_DELETE);
    5847             : 
    5848          20 :         PageSetLSN(page, recptr);
    5849             :     }
    5850             : 
    5851          20 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    5852             : 
    5853          20 :     LockBuffer(buffer, BUFFER_LOCK_UNLOCK);
    5854             : 
    5855          20 :     if (HeapTupleHasExternal(&tp))
    5856             :     {
    5857           2 :         Assert(!IsToastRelation(relation));
    5858           2 :         heap_toast_delete(relation, &tp, true);
    5859             :     }
    5860             : 
    5861             :     /*
    5862             :      * Never need to mark tuple for invalidation, since catalogs don't support
    5863             :      * speculative insertion
    5864             :      */
    5865             : 
    5866             :     /* Now we can release the buffer */
    5867          20 :     ReleaseBuffer(buffer);
    5868             : 
    5869             :     /* count deletion, as we counted the insertion too */
    5870          20 :     pgstat_count_heap_delete(relation);
    5871          20 : }
    5872             : 
    5873             : /*
    5874             :  * heap_inplace_update - update a tuple "in place" (ie, overwrite it)
    5875             :  *
    5876             :  * Overwriting violates both MVCC and transactional safety, so the uses
    5877             :  * of this function in Postgres are extremely limited.  Nonetheless we
    5878             :  * find some places to use it.
    5879             :  *
    5880             :  * The tuple cannot change size, and therefore it's reasonable to assume
    5881             :  * that its null bitmap (if any) doesn't change either.  So we just
    5882             :  * overwrite the data portion of the tuple without touching the null
    5883             :  * bitmap or any of the header fields.
    5884             :  *
    5885             :  * tuple is an in-memory tuple structure containing the data to be written
    5886             :  * over the target tuple.  Also, tuple->t_self identifies the target tuple.
    5887             :  *
    5888             :  * Note that the tuple updated here had better not come directly from the
    5889             :  * syscache if the relation has a toast relation as this tuple could
    5890             :  * include toast values that have been expanded, causing a failure here.
    5891             :  */
    5892             : void
    5893       96018 : heap_inplace_update(Relation relation, HeapTuple tuple)
    5894             : {
    5895             :     Buffer      buffer;
    5896             :     Page        page;
    5897             :     OffsetNumber offnum;
    5898       96018 :     ItemId      lp = NULL;
    5899             :     HeapTupleHeader htup;
    5900             :     uint32      oldlen;
    5901             :     uint32      newlen;
    5902             : 
    5903             :     /*
    5904             :      * For now, we don't allow parallel updates.  Unlike a regular update,
    5905             :      * this should never create a combo CID, so it might be possible to relax
    5906             :      * this restriction, but not without more thought and testing.  It's not
    5907             :      * clear that it would be useful, anyway.
    5908             :      */
    5909       96018 :     if (IsInParallelMode())
    5910           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    5911             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_TRANSACTION_STATE),
    5912             :                  errmsg("cannot update tuples during a parallel operation")));
    5913             : 
    5914       96018 :     buffer = ReadBuffer(relation, ItemPointerGetBlockNumber(&(tuple->t_self)));
    5915       96018 :     LockBuffer(buffer, BUFFER_LOCK_EXCLUSIVE);
    5916       96018 :     page = (Page) BufferGetPage(buffer);
    5917             : 
    5918       96018 :     offnum = ItemPointerGetOffsetNumber(&(tuple->t_self));
    5919       96018 :     if (PageGetMaxOffsetNumber(page) >= offnum)
    5920       96018 :         lp = PageGetItemId(page, offnum);
    5921             : 
    5922       96018 :     if (PageGetMaxOffsetNumber(page) < offnum || !ItemIdIsNormal(lp))
    5923           0 :         elog(ERROR, "invalid lp");
    5924             : 
    5925       96018 :     htup = (HeapTupleHeader) PageGetItem(page, lp);
    5926             : 
    5927       96018 :     oldlen = ItemIdGetLength(lp) - htup->t_hoff;
    5928       96018 :     newlen = tuple->t_len - tuple->t_data->t_hoff;
    5929       96018 :     if (oldlen != newlen || htup->t_hoff != tuple->t_data->t_hoff)
    5930           0 :         elog(ERROR, "wrong tuple length");
    5931             : 
    5932             :     /* NO EREPORT(ERROR) from here till changes are logged */
    5933       96018 :     START_CRIT_SECTION();
    5934             : 
    5935       96018 :     memcpy((char *) htup + htup->t_hoff,
    5936       96018 :            (char *) tuple->t_data + tuple->t_data->t_hoff,
    5937             :            newlen);
    5938             : 
    5939       96018 :     MarkBufferDirty(buffer);
    5940             : 
    5941             :     /* XLOG stuff */
    5942       96018 :     if (RelationNeedsWAL(relation))
    5943             :     {
    5944             :         xl_heap_inplace xlrec;
    5945             :         XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    5946             : 
    5947       96002 :         xlrec.offnum = ItemPointerGetOffsetNumber(&tuple->t_self);
    5948             : 
    5949       96002 :         XLogBeginInsert();
    5950       96002 :         XLogRegisterData((char *) &xlrec, SizeOfHeapInplace);
    5951             : 
    5952       96002 :         XLogRegisterBuffer(0, buffer, REGBUF_STANDARD);
    5953       96002 :         XLogRegisterBufData(0, (char *) htup + htup->t_hoff, newlen);
    5954             : 
    5955             :         /* inplace updates aren't decoded atm, don't log the origin */
    5956             : 
    5957       96002 :         recptr = XLogInsert(RM_HEAP_ID, XLOG_HEAP_INPLACE);
    5958             : 
    5959       96002 :         PageSetLSN(page, recptr);
    5960             :     }
    5961             : 
    5962       96018 :     END_CRIT_SECTION();
    5963             : 
    5964       96018 :     UnlockReleaseBuffer(buffer);
    5965             : 
    5966             :     /*
    5967             :      * Send out shared cache inval if necessary.  Note that because we only
    5968             :      * pass the new version of the tuple, this mustn't be used for any
    5969             :      * operations that could change catcache lookup keys.  But we aren't
    5970             :      * bothering with index updates either, so that's true a fortiori.
    5971             :      */
    5972       96018 :     if (!IsBootstrapProcessingMode())
    5973       77074 :         CacheInvalidateHeapTuple(relation, tuple, NULL);
    5974       96018 : }
    5975             : 
    5976             : #define     FRM_NOOP                0x0001
    5977             : #define     FRM_INVALIDATE_XMAX     0x0002
    5978             : #define     FRM_RETURN_IS_XID       0x0004
    5979             : #define     FRM_RETURN_IS_MULTI     0x0008
    5980             : #define     FRM_MARK_COMMITTED      0x0010
    5981             : 
    5982             : /*
    5983             :  * FreezeMultiXactId
    5984             :  *      Determine what to do during freezing when a tuple is marked by a
    5985             :  *      MultiXactId.
    5986             :  *
    5987             :  * "flags" is an output value; it's used to tell caller what to do on return.
    5988             :  * "pagefrz" is an input/output value, used to manage page level freezing.
    5989             :  *
    5990             :  * Possible values that we can set in "flags":
    5991             :  * FRM_NOOP
    5992             :  *      don't do anything -- keep existing Xmax
    5993             :  * FRM_INVALIDATE_XMAX
    5994             :  *      mark Xmax as InvalidTransactionId and set XMAX_INVALID flag.
    5995             :  * FRM_RETURN_IS_XID
    5996             :  *      The Xid return value is a single update Xid to set as xmax.
    5997             :  * FRM_MARK_COMMITTED
    5998             :  *      Xmax can be marked as HEAP_XMAX_COMMITTED
    5999             :  * FRM_RETURN_IS_MULTI
    6000             :  *      The return value is a new MultiXactId to set as new Xmax.
    6001             :  *      (caller must obtain proper infomask bits using GetMultiXactIdHintBits)
    6002             :  *
    6003             :  * Caller delegates control of page freezing to us.  In practice we always
    6004             :  * force freezing of caller's page unless FRM_NOOP processing is indicated.
    6005             :  * We help caller ensure that XIDs < FreezeLimit and MXIDs < MultiXactCutoff
    6006             :  * can never be left behind.  We freely choose when and how to process each
    6007             :  * Multi, without ever violating the cutoff postconditions for freezing.
    6008             :  *
    6009             :  * It's useful to remove Multis on a proactive timeline (relative to freezing
    6010             :  * XIDs) to keep MultiXact member SLRU buffer misses to a minimum.  It can also
    6011             :  * be cheaper in the short run, for us, since we too can avoid SLRU buffer
    6012             :  * misses through eager processing.
    6013             :  *
    6014             :  * NB: Creates a _new_ MultiXactId when FRM_RETURN_IS_MULTI is set, though only
    6015             :  * when FreezeLimit and/or MultiXactCutoff cutoffs leave us with no choice.
    6016             :  * This can usually be put off, which is usually enough to avoid it altogether.
    6017             :  * Allocating new multis during VACUUM should be avoided on general principle;
    6018             :  * only VACUUM can advance relminmxid, so allocating new Multis here comes with
    6019             :  * its own special risks.
    6020             :  *
    6021             :  * NB: Caller must maintain "no freeze" NewRelfrozenXid/NewRelminMxid trackers
    6022             :  * using heap_tuple_should_freeze when we haven't forced page-level freezing.
    6023             :  *
    6024             :  * NB: Caller should avoid needlessly calling heap_tuple_should_freeze when we
    6025             :  * have already forced page-level freezing, since that might incur the same
    6026             :  * SLRU buffer misses that we specifically intended to avoid by freezing.
    6027             :  */
    6028             : static TransactionId
    6029          14 : FreezeMultiXactId(MultiXactId multi, uint16 t_infomask,
    6030             :                   const struct VacuumCutoffs *cutoffs, uint16 *flags,
    6031             :                   HeapPageFreeze *pagefrz)
    6032             : {
    6033             :     TransactionId newxmax;
    6034             :     MultiXactMember *members;
    6035             :     int         nmembers;
    6036             :     bool        need_replace;
    6037             :     int         nnewmembers;
    6038             :     MultiXactMember *newmembers;
    6039             :     bool        has_lockers;
    6040             :     TransactionId update_xid;
    6041             :     bool        update_committed;
    6042             :     TransactionId FreezePageRelfrozenXid;
    6043             : 
    6044          14 :     *flags = 0;
    6045             : 
    6046             :     /* We should only be called in Multis */
    6047          14 :     Assert(t_infomask & HEAP_XMAX_IS_MULTI);
    6048             : 
    6049          14 :     if (!MultiXactIdIsValid(multi) ||
    6050          14 :         HEAP_LOCKED_UPGRADED(t_infomask))
    6051             :     {
    6052           0 :         *flags |= FRM_INVALIDATE_XMAX;
    6053           0 :         pagefrz->freeze_required = true;
    6054           0 :         return InvalidTransactionId;
    6055             :     }
    6056          14 :     else if (MultiXactIdPrecedes(multi, cutoffs->relminmxid))
    6057           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    6058             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_DATA_CORRUPTED),
    6059             :                  errmsg_internal("found multixact %u from before relminmxid %u",
    6060             :                                  multi, cutoffs->relminmxid)));
    6061          14 :     else if (MultiXactIdPrecedes(multi, cutoffs->OldestMxact))
    6062             :     {
    6063             :         TransactionId update_xact;
    6064             : 
    6065             :         /*
    6066             :          * This old multi cannot possibly have members still running, but
    6067             :          * verify just in case.  If it was a locker only, it can be removed
    6068             :          * without any further consideration; but if it contained an update,
    6069             :          * we might need to preserve it.
    6070             :          */
    6071          10 :         if (MultiXactIdIsRunning(multi,
    6072          10 :                                  HEAP_XMAX_IS_LOCKED_ONLY(t_infomask)))
    6073           0 :             ereport(ERROR,
    6074             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_DATA_CORRUPTED),
    6075             :                      errmsg_internal("multixact %u from before multi freeze cutoff %u found to be still running",
    6076             :                                      multi, cutoffs->OldestMxact)));
    6077             : 
    6078          10 :         if (HEAP_XMAX_IS_LOCKED_ONLY(t_infomask))
    6079             :         {
    6080          10 :             *flags |= FRM_INVALIDATE_XMAX;
    6081          10 :             pagefrz->freeze_required = true;
    6082          10 :             return InvalidTransactionId;
    6083             :         }
    6084             : 
    6085             :         /* replace multi with single XID for its updater? */
    6086           0 :         update_xact = MultiXactIdGetUpdateXid(multi, t_infomask);
    6087           0 :         if (TransactionIdPrecedes(update_xact, cutoffs->relfrozenxid))
    6088           0 :             ereport(ERROR,
    6089             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_DATA_CORRUPTED),
    6090             :                      errmsg_internal("multixact %u contains update XID %u from before relfrozenxid %u",
    6091             :                                      multi, update_xact,
    6092             :                                      cutoffs->relfrozenxid)));
    6093           0 :         else if (TransactionIdPrecedes(update_xact, cutoffs->OldestXmin))
    6094             :         {
    6095             :             /*
    6096             :              * Updater XID has to have aborted (otherwise the tuple would have
    6097             :              * been pruned away instead, since updater XID is < OldestXmin).
    6098             :              * Just remove xmax.
    6099             :              */
    6100           0 :             if (TransactionIdDidCommit(update_xact))
    6101           0 :                 ereport(ERROR,
    6102             :                         (errcode(ERRCODE_DATA_CORRUPTED),
    6103             :                          errmsg_internal("multixact %u contains committed update XID %u from before removable cutoff %u",
    6104             :                                          multi, update_xact,
    6105             :                                          cutoffs->OldestXmin)));
    6106           0 :             *flags |= FRM_INVALIDATE_XMAX;
    6107           0 :             pagefrz->freeze_required = true;
    6108           0 :             return InvalidTransactionId;
    6109             :         }
    6110             : 
    6111             :         /* Have to keep updater XID as new xmax */
    6112           0 :         *flags |= FRM_RETURN_IS_XID;
    6113           0 :         pagefrz->freeze_required = true;
    6114           0 :         return update_xact;
    6115             :     }
    6116             : 
    6117             :     /*
    6118             :      * Some member(s) of this Multi may be below FreezeLimit xid cutoff, so we
    6119             :      * need to walk the whole members array to figure out what to do, if
    6120             :      * anything.
    6121             :      */
    6122             :     nmembers =
    6123           4 :         GetMultiXactIdMembers(multi, &members, false,
    6124           4 :                               HEAP_XMAX_IS_LOCKED_ONLY(t_infomask));
    6125           4 :     if (nmembers <= 0)
    6126             :     {
    6127             :         /* Nothing worth keeping */
    6128           0 :         *flags |= FRM_INVALIDATE_XMAX;
    6129           0 :         pagefrz->freeze_required = true;
    6130           0 :         return InvalidTransactionId;
    6131             :     }
    6132             : 
    6133             :     /*
    6134             :      * The FRM_NOOP case is the only case where we might need to ratchet back
    6135             :      * FreezePageRelfrozenXid or FreezePageRelminMxid.  It is also the only
    6136             :      * case where our caller might ratchet back its NoFreezePageRelfrozenXid
    6137             :      * or NoFreezePageRelminMxid "no freeze" trackers to deal with a multi.
    6138             :      * FRM_NOOP handling should result in the NewRelfrozenXid/NewRelminMxid
    6139             :      * trackers managed by VACUUM being ratcheting back by xmax to the degree
    6140             :      * required to make it safe to leave xmax undisturbed, independent of
    6141             :      * whether or not page freezing is triggered somewhere else.
    6142             :      *
    6143             :      * Our policy is to force freezing in every case other than FRM_NOOP,
    6144             :      * which obviates the need to maintain either set of trackers, anywhere.
    6145             :      * Every other case will reliably execute a freeze plan for xmax that
    6146             :      * either replaces xmax with an XID/MXID >= OldestXmin/OldestMxact, or
    6147             :      * sets xmax to an InvalidTransactionId XID, rendering xmax fully frozen.
    6148             :      * (VACUUM's NewRelfrozenXid/NewRelminMxid trackers are initialized with
    6149             :      * OldestXmin/OldestMxact, so later values never need to be tracked here.)
    6150             :      */
    6151           4 :     need_replace = false;
    6152           4 :     FreezePageRelfrozenXid = pagefrz->FreezePageRelfrozenXid;
    6153           8 :     for (int i = 0; i < nmembers; i++)
    6154             :     {
    6155           6 :         TransactionId xid = members[i].xid;
    6156             : 
    6157           6 :         Assert(!TransactionIdPrecedes(xid, cutoffs->relfrozenxid));
    6158             : 
    6159           6 :         if (TransactionIdPrecedes(xid, cutoffs->FreezeLimit))
    6160             :         {
    6161             :             /* Can't violate the FreezeLimit postcondition */
    6162           2 :             need_replace = true;
    6163           2 :             break;
    6164             :         }
    6165           4 :         if (TransactionIdPrecedes(xid, FreezePageRelfrozenXid))
    6166           0 :             FreezePageRelfrozenXid = xid;
    6167             :     }
    6168             : 
    6169             :     /* Can't violate the MultiXactCutoff postcondition, either */
    6170           4 :     if (!need_replace)
    6171           2 :         need_replace = MultiXactIdPrecedes(multi, cutoffs->MultiXactCutoff);
    6172             : 
    6173           4 :     if (!need_replace)
    6174             :     {
    6175             :         /*
    6176             :          * vacuumlazy.c might ratchet back NewRelminMxid, NewRelfrozenXid, or

    6178             :          * freezing its page
    6179             :          */
    6180           2 :         *flags |= FRM_NOOP;
    6181           2 :         pagefrz->FreezePageRelfrozenXid = FreezePageRelfrozenXid;

    6184           2 :         pfree(members);

    6186             :     }
    6187             : 
    6188             :     /*
    6189             :      * Do a more thorough second pass over the multi to figure out which
    6190             :      * member XIDs actually need to be kept.  Checking the precise status of
    6191             :      * individual members might even show that we don't need to keep anything.
    6192             :      * That is quite possible even though the Multi must be >= OldestMxact,
    6193             :      * since our second pass only keeps member XIDs when it's truly necessary;
    6194             :      * even member XIDs >= OldestXmin often won't be kept by second pass.
    6195             :      */
    6196           2 :     nnewmembers = 0;
    6197           2 :     newmembers = palloc(sizeof(MultiXactMember) * nmembers);
    6198           2 :     has_lockers = false;
    6199           2 :     update_xid = InvalidTransactionId;
    6200           2 :     update_committed = false;
    6201             : 
    6202             :     /*
    6203             :      * Determine whether to keep each member xid, or to ignore it instead
    6204             :      */
    6205           6 :     for (int i = 0; i < nmembers; i++)
    6206             :     {
    6207           4 :         TransactionId xid = members[i].xid;
    6208           4 :         MultiXactStatus mstatus = members[i].status;
    6209             : 
    6210           4 :         Assert(!TransactionIdPrecedes(xid, cutoffs->relfrozenxid));
    6211             : 
    6212           4 :         if (!ISUPDATE_from_mxstatus(mstatus))
    6213             :         {
    6214             :             /*
    6215             :              * Locker XID (not updater XID).  We only keep lockers that are
    6216             :              * still running.
    6217             :              */
    6218           8 :             if (TransactionIdIsCurrentTransactionId(xid) ||
    6219           4 :                 TransactionIdIsInProgress(xid))
    6220             :             {
    6221           2 :                 if (TransactionIdPrecedes(xid, cutoffs->OldestXmin))
    6222           0 :                     ereport(ERROR,
    6223             :                             (errcode(ERRCODE_DATA_CORRUPTED),
    6224             :                              errmsg_internal("multixact %u contains running locker XID %u from before removable cutoff %u",

    6226             :                                              cutoffs->OldestXmin)));
    6227           2 :                 newmembers[nnewmembers++] = members[i];
    6228           2 :                 has_lockers = true;
    6229             :             }
    6230             : 
    6231           4 :             continue;
    6232             :         }
    6233             : 
    6234             :         /*
    6235             :          * Updater XID (not locker XID).  Should we keep it?
    6236             :          *
    6237             :          * Since the tuple wasn't totally removed when vacuum pruned, the
    6238             :          * update Xid cannot possibly be older than OldestXmin cutoff unless
    6239             :          * the updater XID aborted.  If the updater transaction is known
    6240             :          * aborted or crashed then it's okay to ignore it, otherwise not.
    6241             :          *
    6242             :          * In any case the Multi should never contain two updaters, whatever
    6243             :          * their individual commit status.  Check for that first, in passing.
    6244             :          */
    6245           0 :         if (TransactionIdIsValid(update_xid))
    6246           0 :             ereport(ERROR,
    6247             :                     (errcode(ERRCODE_DATA_CORRUPTED),

    6250             :                      errdetail_internal("First updater XID=%u second updater XID=%u.",

    6334             : 
    6335             : /*
    6336             :  * heap_prepare_freeze_tuple
    6337             :  *
    6338             :  * Check to see whether any of the XID fields of a tuple (xmin, xmax, xvac)
    6339             :  * are older than the OldestXmin and/or OldestMxact freeze cutoffs.  If so,
    6340             :  * setup enough state (in the *frz output argument) to enable caller to
    6341             :  * process this tuple as part of freezing its page, and return true.  Return
    6342             :  * false if nothing can be changed about the tuple right now.
    6343             :  *
    6344             :  * Also sets *totally_frozen to true if the tuple will be totally frozen once
    6345             :  * caller executes returned freeze plan (or if the tuple was already totally
    6346             :  * frozen by an earlier VACUUM).  This indicates that there are no remaining
    6347             :  * XIDs or MultiXactIds that will need to be processed by a future VACUUM.
    6348             :  *
    6349             :  * VACUUM caller must assemble HeapTupleFreeze freeze plan entries for every
    6350             :  * tuple that we returned true for, and call heap_freeze_execute_prepared to
    6351             :  * execute freezing.  Caller must initialize pagefrz fields for page as a
    6352             :  * whole before first call here for each heap page.
    6353             :  *
    6354             :  * VACUUM caller decides on whether or not to freeze the page as a whole.
    6355             :  * We'll often prepare freeze plans for a page that caller just discards.
    6356             :  * However, VACUUM doesn't always get to make a choice; it must freeze when
    6357             :  * pagefrz.freeze_required is set, to ensure that any XIDs < FreezeLimit (and
    6358             :  * MXIDs < MultiXactCutoff) can never be left behind.  We help to make sure
    6359             :  * that VACUUM always follows that rule.
    6360             :  *
    6361             :  * We sometimes force freezing of xmax MultiXactId values long before it is
    6362             :  * strictly necessary to do so just to ensure the FreezeLimit postcondition.
    6363             :  * It's worth processing MultiXactIds proactively when it is cheap to do so,
    6364             :  * and it's convenient to make that happen by piggy-backing it on the "force
    6365             :  * freezing" mechanism.  Conversely, we sometimes delay freezing MultiXactIds
    6366             :  * because it is expensive right now (though only when it's still possible to
    6367             :  * do so without violating the FreezeLimit/MultiXactCutoff postcondition).
    6368             :  *
    6369             :  * It is assumed that the caller has checked the tuple with
    6370             :  * HeapTupleSatisfiesVacuum() and determined that it is not HEAPTUPLE_DEAD
    6371             :  * (else we should be removing the tuple, not freezing it).
    6372             :  *
    6373             :  * NB: This function has side effects: it might allocate a new MultiXactId.
    6374             :  * It will be set as tuple's new xmax when our *frz output is processed within
    6375             :  * heap_execute_freeze_tuple later on.  If the tuple is in a shared buffer
    6376             :  * then caller had better have an exclusive lock on it already.
    6377             :  */
    6378             : bool
    6379     5846180 : heap_prepare_freeze_tuple(HeapTupleHeader tuple,
    6380             :                           const struct VacuumCutoffs *cutoffs,

    6643             : /*
    6644             :  * heap_execute_freeze_tuple
    6645             :  *      Execute the prepared freezing of a tuple with caller's freeze plan.
    6646             :  *
    6647             :  * Caller is responsible for ensuring that no other backend can access the
    6648             :  * storage underlying this tuple, either by holding an exclusive lock on the
    6649             :  * buffer containing it (which is what lazy VACUUM does), or by having it be
    6650             :  * in private storage (which is what CLUSTER and friends do).
    6651             :  */
    6652             : static inline void
    6653     1307848 : heap_execute_freeze_tuple(HeapTupleHeader tuple, HeapTupleFreeze *frz)
    6654             : {
    6655     1307848 :     HeapTupleHeaderSetXmax(tuple, frz->xmax);
    6656             : 
    6657     1307848 :     if (frz->frzflags & XLH_FREEZE_XVAC)
    6658           0 :         HeapTupleHeaderSetXvac(tuple, FrozenTransactionId);
    6659             : 
    6660     1307848 :     if (frz->frzflags & XLH_INVALID_XVAC)
    6661           0 :         HeapTupleHeaderSetXvac(tuple, InvalidTransactionId);
    6662             : 
    6663     1307848 :     tuple->t_infomask = frz->t_infomask;
    6664     1307848 :     tuple->t_infomask2 = frz->t_infomask2;
    6665     1307848 : }
    6666             : 
    6667             : /*
    6668             :  * heap_freeze_execute_prepared
    6669             :  *
    6670             :  * Executes freezing of one or more heap tuples on a page on behalf of caller.
    6671             :  * Caller passes an array of tuple plans from heap_prepare_freeze_tuple.
    6672             :  * Caller must set 'offset' in each plan for us.  Note that we destructively
    6673             :  * sort caller's tuples array in-place, so caller had better be done with it.
    6674             :  *
    6675             :  * WAL-logs the changes so that VACUUM can advance the rel's relfrozenxid
    6676             :  * later on without any risk of unsafe pg_xact lookups, even following a hard
    6677             :  * crash (or when querying from a standby).  We represent freezing by setting
    6678             :  * infomask bits in tuple headers, but this shouldn't be thought of as a hint.
    6679             :  * See section on buffer access rules in src/backend/storage/buffer/README.
    6680             :  */
    6681             : void
    6682       18272 : heap_freeze_execute_prepared(Relation rel, Buffer buffer,
    6683             :                              TransactionId snapshotConflictHorizon,
    6684             :                              HeapTupleFreeze *tuples, int ntuples)
    6685             : {
    6686       18272 :     Page        page = BufferGetPage(buffer);
    6687             : 
    6688       18272 :     Assert(ntuples > 0);
    6689             : 
    6690             :     /*
    6691             :      * Perform xmin/xmax XID status sanity checks before critical section.
    6692             :      *
    6693             :      * heap_prepare_freeze_tuple doesn't perform these checks directly because
    6694             :      * pg_xact lookups are relatively expensive.  They shouldn't be repeated
    6695             :      * by successive VACUUMs that each decide against freezing the same page.
    6696             :      */

    6789             :  * Comparator used to deduplicate XLOG_HEAP2_FREEZE_PAGE freeze plans

    6851             : /*

    6864             : 
    6865             : /*
    6866             :  * Deduplicate tuple-based freeze plans so that each distinct set of
    6867             :  * processing steps is only stored once in XLOG_HEAP2_FREEZE_PAGE records.
    6868             :  * Called during original execution of freezing (for logged relations).
    6869             :  *
    6870             :  * Return value is number of plans set in *plans_out for caller.  Also writes
    6871             :  * an array of offset numbers into *offsets_out output argument for caller

    6873             :  * concern to our caller).

    7116             : /*
    7117             :  * Does the given multixact conflict with the current transaction grabbing a
    7118             :  * tuple lock of the given strength?
    7119             :  *
    7120             :  * The passed infomask pairs up with the given multixact in the tuple header.
    7121             :  *
    7122             :  * If current_is_member is not NULL, it is set to 'true' if the current
    7123             :  * transaction is a member of the given multixact.
    7124             :  */
    7125             : static bool
    7126         188 : DoesMultiXactIdConflict(MultiXactId multi, uint16 infomask,

    7195             : 
    7196             : /*
    7197             :  * Do_MultiXactIdWait
    7198             :  *      Actual implementation for the two functions below.
    7199             :  *
    7200             :  * 'multi', 'status' and 'infomask' indicate what to sleep on (the status is
    7201             :  * needed to ensure we only sleep on conflicting members, and the infomask is
    7202             :  * used to optimize multixact access in case it's a lock-only multi); 'nowait'
    7203             :  * indicates whether to use conditional lock acquisition, to allow callers to
    7204             :  * fail if lock is unavailable.  'rel', 'ctid' and 'oper' are used to set up
    7205             :  * context information for error messages.  'remaining', if not NULL, receives
    7206             :  * the number of members that are still running, including any (non-aborted)
    7207             :  * subtransactions of our own transaction.
    7208             :  *
    7209             :  * We do this by sleeping on each member using XactLockTableWait.  Any
    7210             :  * members that belong to the current backend are *not* waited for, however;
    7211             :  * this would not merely be useless but would lead to Assert failure inside
    7212             :  * XactLockTableWait.  By the time this returns, it is certain that all
    7213             :  * transactions *of other backends* that were members of the MultiXactId
    7214             :  * that conflict with the requested status are dead (and no new ones can have
    7215             :  * been added, since it is not legal to add members to an existing
    7216             :  * MultiXactId).
    7217             :  *
    7218             :  * But by the time we finish sleeping, someone else may have changed the Xmax
    7219             :  * of the containing tuple, so the caller needs to iterate on us somehow.
    7220             :  *
    7221             :  * Note that in case we return false, the number of remaining members is
    7222             :  * not to be trusted.
    7223             :  */
    7224             : static bool
    7225         112 : Do_MultiXactIdWait(MultiXactId multi, MultiXactStatus status,
    7226             :                    uint16 infomask, bool nowait,
    7227             :                    Relation rel, ItemPointer ctid, XLTW_Oper oper,
    7228             :                    int *remaining)
    7229             : {
    7230         112 :     bool        result = true;
    7231             :     MultiXactMember *members;
    7232             :     int         nmembers;
    7233         112 :     int         remain = 0;
    7234             : 
    7235             :     /* for pre-pg_upgrade tuples, no need to sleep at all */
    7236         112 :     nmembers = HEAP_LOCKED_UPGRADED(infomask) ? -1 :
    7237         112 :         GetMultiXactIdMembers(multi, &members, false,
    7238         112 :                               HEAP_XMAX_IS_LOCKED_ONLY(infomask));
    7239             : 
    7240         112 :     if (nmembers >= 0)
    7241             :     {
    7242             :         int         i;
    7243             : 
    7244         362 :         for (i = 0; i < nmembers; i++)
    7245             :         {
    7246         258 :             TransactionId memxid = members[i].xid;
    7247         258 :             MultiXactStatus memstatus = members[i].status;
    7248             : 
    7249         258 :             if (TransactionIdIsCurrentTransactionId(memxid))
    7250             :             {
    7251          48 :                 remain++;
    7252          48 :                 continue;
    7253             :             }
    7254             : 
    7255         210 :             if (!DoLockModesConflict(LOCKMODE_from_mxstatus(memstatus),
    7256         210 :                                      LOCKMODE_from_mxstatus(status)))
    7257             :             {
    7258          40 :                 if (remaining && TransactionIdIsInProgress(memxid))
    7259          12 :                     remain++;
    7260          40 :                 continue;
    7261             :             }
    7262             : 
    7263             :             /*
    7264             :              * This member conflicts with our multi, so we have to sleep (or
    7265             :              * return failure, if asked to avoid waiting.)
    7266             :              *
    7267             :              * Note that we don't set up an error context callback ourselves,
    7268             :              * but instead we pass the info down to XactLockTableWait.  This
    7269             :              * might seem a bit wasteful because the context is set up and
    7270             :              * tore down for each member of the multixact, but in reality it
    7271             :              * should be barely noticeable, and it avoids duplicate code.
    7272             :              */
    7273         170 :             if (nowait)
    7274             :             {
    7275           8 :                 result = ConditionalXactLockTableWait(memxid);
    7276           8 :                 if (!result)
    7277           8 :                     break;
    7278             :             }
    7279             :             else
    7280         162 :                 XactLockTableWait(memxid, rel, ctid, oper);
    7281             :         }
    7282             : 
    7283         112 :         pfree(members);
    7284             :     }
    7285             : 
    7286         112 :     if (remaining)
    7287          16 :         *remaining = remain;
    7288             : 
    7289         112 :     return result;
    7290             : }
    7291             : 
    7292             : /*
    7293             :  * MultiXactIdWait
    7294             :  *      Sleep on a MultiXactId.
    7295             :  *
    7296             :  * By the time we finish sleeping, someone else may have changed the Xmax
    7297             :  * of the containing tuple, so the caller needs to iterate on us somehow.
    7298             :  *
    7299             :  * We return (in *remaining, if not NULL) the number of members that are still
    7300             :  * running, including any (non-aborted) subtransactions of our own transaction.
    7301             :  */
    7302             : static void
    7303         104 : MultiXactIdWait(MultiXactId multi, MultiXactStatus status, uint16 infomask,
    7304             :                 Relation rel, ItemPointer ctid, XLTW_Oper oper,
    7305             :                 int *remaining)
    7306             : {
    7307         104 :     (void) Do_MultiXactIdWait(multi, status, infomask, false,
    7308             :                               rel, ctid, oper, remaining);
    7309         104 : }
    7310             : 
    7311             : /*
    7312             :  * ConditionalMultiXactIdWait
    7313             :  *      As above, but only lock if we can get the lock without blocking.
    7314             :  *
    7315             :  * By the time we finish sleeping, someone else may have changed the Xmax
    7316             :  * of the containing tuple, so the caller needs to iterate on us somehow.
    7317             :  *
    7318             :  * If the multixact is now all gone, return true.  Returns false if some
    7319             :  * transactions might still be running.
    7320             :  *
    7321             :  * We return (in *remaining, if not NULL) the number of members that are still
    7322             :  * running, including any (non-aborted) subtransactions of our own transaction.
    7323             :  */
    7324             : static bool
    7325           8 : ConditionalMultiXactIdWait(MultiXactId multi, MultiXactStatus status,
    7326             :                            uint16 infomask, Relation rel, int *remaining)
    7327             : {
    7328           8 :     return Do_MultiXactIdWait(multi, status, infomask, true,
    7329             :                               rel, NULL, XLTW_None, remaining);
    7330             : }
    7331             : 
    7332             : /*

    7379             : /*
    7380             :  * heap_tuple_should_freeze
    7381             :  *
    7382             :  * Return value indicates if heap_prepare_freeze_tuple sibling function would
    7383             :  * (or should) force freezing of the heap page that contains caller's tuple.
    7384             :  * Tuple header XIDs/MXIDs < FreezeLimit/MultiXactCutoff trigger freezing.
    7385             :  * This includes (xmin, xmax, xvac) fields, as well as MultiXact member XIDs.
    7386             :  *
    7387             :  * The *NoFreezePageRelfrozenXid and *NoFreezePageRelminMxid input/output
    7388             :  * arguments help VACUUM track the oldest extant XID/MXID remaining in rel.
    7389             :  * Our working assumption is that caller won't decide to freeze this tuple.
    7390             :  * It's up to caller to only ratchet back its own top-level trackers after the
    7391             :  * point that it fully commits to not freezing the tuple/page in question.
    7392             :  */
    7393             : bool
    7394     2804538 : heap_tuple_should_freeze(HeapTupleHeader tuple,

    7488             : /*
    7489             :  * Maintain snapshotConflictHorizon for caller by ratcheting forward its value
    7490             :  * using any committed XIDs contained in 'tuple', an obsolescent heap tuple
    7491             :  * that caller is in the process of physically removing, e.g. via HOT pruning
    7492             :  * or index deletion.
    7493             :  *
    7494             :  * Caller must initialize its value to InvalidTransactionId, which is
    7495             :  * generally interpreted as "definitely no need for a recovery conflict".
    7496             :  * Final value must reflect all heap tuples that caller will physically remove
    7497             :  * (or remove TID references to) via its ongoing pruning/deletion operation.
    7498             :  * ResolveRecoveryConflictWithSnapshot() is passed the final value (taken from
    7499             :  * caller's WAL record) by REDO routine when it replays caller's operation.
    7500             :  */
    7501             : void

    7530             : #ifdef USE_PREFETCH
    7531             : /*
    7532             :  * Helper function for heap_index_delete_tuples.  Issues prefetch requests for
    7533             :  * prefetch_count buffers.  The prefetch_state keeps track of all the buffers
    7534             :  * we can prefetch, and which have already been prefetched; each call to this
    7535             :  * function picks up where the previous call left off.
    7536             :  *
    7537             :  * Note: we expect the deltids array to be sorted in an order that groups TIDs
    7538             :  * by heap block, with all TIDs for each block appearing together in exactly
    7539             :  * one group.
    7540             :  */

    7576             : /*
    7577             :  * Helper function for heap_index_delete_tuples.  Checks for index corruption
    7578             :  * involving an invalid TID in index AM caller's index page.
    7579             :  *
    7580             :  * This is an ideal place for these checks.  The index AM must hold a buffer
    7581             :  * lock on the index page containing the TIDs we examine here, so we don't
    7582             :  * have to worry about concurrent VACUUMs at all.  We can be sure that the
    7583             :  * index is corrupt when htid points directly to an LP_UNUSED item or
    7584             :  * heap-only tuple, which is not the case during standard index scans.
    7585             :  */
