    7632             : 
    7633             : /*
    7634             :  * heapam implementation of tableam's index_delete_tuples interface.
    7635             :  *
    7636             :  * This helper function is called by index AMs during index tuple deletion.
    7637             :  * See tableam header comments for an explanation of the interface implemented
    7638             :  * here and a general theory of operation.  Note that each call here is either
    7639             :  * a simple index deletion call, or a bottom-up index deletion call.
    7640             :  *
    7641             :  * It's possible for this to generate a fair amount of I/O, since we may be
    7642             :  * deleting hundreds of tuples from a single index block.  To amortize that
    7643             :  * cost to some degree, this uses prefetching and combines repeat accesses to
    7644             :  * the same heap block.
    7645             :  */
    7646             : TransactionId
    7647        9738 : heap_index_delete_tuples(Relation rel, TM_IndexDeleteOp *delstate)
    7648             : {
    7649             :     /* Initial assumption is that earlier pruning took care of conflict */
    7650        9738 :     TransactionId snapshotConflictHorizon = InvalidTransactionId;
    7651        9738 :     BlockNumber blkno = InvalidBlockNumber;
    7652        9738 :     Buffer      buf = InvalidBuffer;
    7653        9738 :     Page        page = NULL;
    7654        9738 :     OffsetNumber maxoff = InvalidOffsetNumber;
    7655             :     TransactionId priorXmax;
    7656             : #ifdef USE_PREFETCH
    7657             :     IndexDeletePrefetchState prefetch_state;
    7658             :     int         prefetch_distance;
    7659             : #endif
    7660             :     SnapshotData SnapshotNonVacuumable;
    7661        9738 :     int         finalndeltids = 0,
    7662        9738 :                 nblocksaccessed = 0;
    7663             : 
    7664             :     /* State that's only used in bottom-up index deletion case */
    7665        9738 :     int         nblocksfavorable = 0;
    7666        9738 :     int         curtargetfreespace = delstate->bottomupfreespace,
    7667        9738 :                 lastfreespace = 0,
    7668        9738 :                 actualfreespace = 0;
    7669        9738 :     bool        bottomup_final_block = false;
    7670             : 
    7671        9738 :     InitNonVacuumableSnapshot(SnapshotNonVacuumable, GlobalVisTestFor(rel));
    7672             : 
    7673             :     /* Sort caller's deltids array by TID for further processing */
    7674        9738 :     index_delete_sort(delstate);
    7675             : 
    7676             :     /*
    7677             :      * Bottom-up case: resort deltids array in an order attuned to where the
    7678             :      * greatest number of promising TIDs are to be found, and determine how
    7679             :      * many blocks from the start of sorted array should be considered
    7680             :      * favorable.  This will also shrink the deltids array in order to
    7681             :      * eliminate completely unfavorable blocks up front.
    7682             :      */
    7683        9738 :     if (delstate->bottomup)
    7684        3246 :         nblocksfavorable = bottomup_sort_and_shrink(delstate);
    7685             : 
    7686             : #ifdef USE_PREFETCH
    7687             :     /* Initialize prefetch state. */
    7688        9738 :     prefetch_state.cur_hblkno = InvalidBlockNumber;
    7689        9738 :     prefetch_state.next_item = 0;
    7690        9738 :     prefetch_state.ndeltids = delstate->ndeltids;
    7691        9738 :     prefetch_state.deltids = delstate->deltids;
    7692             : 
    7693             :     /*
    7694             :      * Determine the prefetch distance that we will attempt to maintain.
    7695             :      *
    7696             :      * Since the caller holds a buffer lock somewhere in rel, we'd better make
    7697             :      * sure that isn't a catalog relation before we call code that does
    7698             :      * syscache lookups, to avoid risk of deadlock.
    7699             :      */
    7700        9738 :     if (IsCatalogRelation(rel))
    7701        6542 :         prefetch_distance = maintenance_io_concurrency;
    7702             :     else
    7703             :         prefetch_distance =
    7704        3196 :             get_tablespace_maintenance_io_concurrency(rel->rd_rel->reltablespace);
    7705             : 
    7706             :     /* Cap initial prefetch distance for bottom-up deletion caller */
    7707        9738 :     if (delstate->bottomup)
    7708             :     {
    7709        3246 :         Assert(nblocksfavorable >= 1);
    7710        3246 :         Assert(nblocksfavorable <= BOTTOMUP_MAX_NBLOCKS);
    7711        3246 :         prefetch_distance = Min(prefetch_distance, nblocksfavorable);
    7712             :     }
    7713             : 
    7714             :     /* Start prefetching. */
    7715        9738 :     index_delete_prefetch_buffer(rel, &prefetch_state, prefetch_distance);
    7716             : #endif
    7717             : 
    7718             :     /* Iterate over deltids, determine which to delete, check their horizon */
    7719        9738 :     Assert(delstate->ndeltids > 0);
    7720      950650 :     for (int i = 0; i < delstate->ndeltids; i++)
    7721             :     {
    7722      944158 :         TM_IndexDelete *ideltid = &delstate->deltids[i];
    7723      944158 :         TM_IndexStatus *istatus = delstate->status + ideltid->id;
    7724      944158 :         ItemPointer htid = &ideltid->tid;
    7725             :         OffsetNumber offnum;
    7726             : 
    7727             :         /*
    7728             :          * Read buffer, and perform required extra steps each time a new block
    7729             :          * is encountered.  Avoid refetching if it's the same block as the one
    7730             :          * from the last htid.
    7731             :          */
    7732     1878578 :         if (blkno == InvalidBlockNumber ||
    7733      934420 :             ItemPointerGetBlockNumber(htid) != blkno)
    7734             :         {
    7735             :             /*
    7736             :              * Consider giving up early for bottom-up index deletion caller
    7737             :              * first. (Only prefetch next-next block afterwards, when it
    7738             :              * becomes clear that we're at least going to access the next
    7739             :              * block in line.)
    7740             :              *
    7741             :              * Sometimes the first block frees so much space for bottom-up
    7742             :              * caller that the deletion process can end without accessing any
    7743             :              * more blocks.  It is usually necessary to access 2 or 3 blocks
    7744             :              * per bottom-up deletion operation, though.
    7745             :              */
    7746       25618 :             if (delstate->bottomup)
    7747             :             {
    7748             :                 /*
    7749             :                  * We often allow caller to delete a few additional items
    7750             :                  * whose entries we reached after the point that space target
    7751             :                  * from caller was satisfied.  The cost of accessing the page
    7752             :                  * was already paid at that point, so it made sense to finish
    7753             :                  * it off.  When that happened, we finalize everything here
    7754             :                  * (by finishing off the whole bottom-up deletion operation
    7755             :                  * without needlessly paying the cost of accessing any more
    7756             :                  * blocks).
    7757             :                  */
    7758        6828 :                 if (bottomup_final_block)
    7759         232 :                     break;
    7760             : 
    7761             :                 /*
    7762             :                  * Give up when we didn't enable our caller to free any
    7763             :                  * additional space as a result of processing the page that we
    7764             :                  * just finished up with.  This rule is the main way in which
    7765             :                  * we keep the cost of bottom-up deletion under control.
    7766             :                  */
    7767        6596 :                 if (nblocksaccessed >= 1 && actualfreespace == lastfreespace)
    7768        3014 :                     break;
    7769        3582 :                 lastfreespace = actualfreespace;    /* for next time */
    7770             : 
    7771             :                 /*
    7772             :                  * Deletion operation (which is bottom-up) will definitely
    7773             :                  * access the next block in line.  Prepare for that now.
    7774             :                  *
    7775             :                  * Decay target free space so that we don't hang on for too
    7776             :                  * long with a marginal case. (Space target is only truly
    7777             :                  * helpful when it allows us to recognize that we don't need
    7778             :                  * to access more than 1 or 2 blocks to satisfy caller due to
    7779             :                  * agreeable workload characteristics.)
    7780             :                  *
    7781             :                  * We are a bit more patient when we encounter contiguous
    7782             :                  * blocks, though: these are treated as favorable blocks.  The
    7783             :                  * decay process is only applied when the next block in line
    7784             :                  * is not a favorable/contiguous block.  This is not an
    7785             :                  * exception to the general rule; we still insist on finding
    7786             :                  * at least one deletable item per block accessed.  See
    7787             :                  * bottomup_nblocksfavorable() for full details of the theory
    7788             :                  * behind favorable blocks and heap block locality in general.
    7789             :                  *
    7790             :                  * Note: The first block in line is always treated as a
    7791             :                  * favorable block, so the earliest possible point that the
    7792             :                  * decay can be applied is just before we access the second
    7793             :                  * block in line.  The Assert() verifies this for us.
    7794             :                  */
    7795        3582 :                 Assert(nblocksaccessed > 0 || nblocksfavorable > 0);
    7796        3582 :                 if (nblocksfavorable > 0)
    7797        3412 :                     nblocksfavorable--;

    7799         170 :                     curtargetfreespace /= 2;
    7800             :             }
    7801             : 
    7802             :             /* release old buffer */
    7803       22372 :             if (BufferIsValid(buf))

    7805             : 
    7806       22372 :             blkno = ItemPointerGetBlockNumber(htid);
    7807       22372 :             buf = ReadBuffer(rel, blkno);
    7808       22372 :             nblocksaccessed++;
    7809       22372 :             Assert(!delstate->bottomup ||
    7810             :                    nblocksaccessed <= BOTTOMUP_MAX_NBLOCKS);
    7811             : 
    7812             : #ifdef USE_PREFETCH
    7813             : 
    7814             :             /*
    7815             :              * To maintain the prefetch distance, prefetch one more page for
    7816             :              * each page we read.
    7817             :              */

    7827             :         /*

    7833      940912 :         index_delete_check_htid(delstate, page, maxoff, htid, istatus);
    7834             : 
    7835      940912 :         if (istatus->knowndeletable)
    7836      248072 :             Assert(!delstate->bottomup && !istatus->promising);

    7838             :         {
    7839      692840 :             ItemPointerData tmp = *htid;
    7840             :             HeapTupleData heapTuple;

    7842             :             /* Are any tuples from this HOT chain non-vacuumable? */

    7845      419824 :                 continue;       /* can't delete entry */

    7859             : 
    7860             :         /*

    7863             :          * loosely based on the logic for pruning a HOT chain.
    7864             :          */
    7865      521088 :         offnum = ItemPointerGetOffsetNumber(htid);
    7866      521088 :         priorXmax = InvalidTransactionId;   /* cannot check first XMIN */
    7867             :         for (;;)
    7868       38352 :         {
    7869             :             ItemId      lp;
    7870             :             HeapTupleHeader htup;
    7871             : 
    7872             :             /* Sanity check (pure paranoia) */
    7873      559440 :             if (offnum < FirstOffsetNumber)
    7874           0 :                 break;
    7875             :

    7880      559440 :             if (offnum > maxoff)
    7881           0 :                 break;
    7882             :

    7884      559440 :             if (ItemIdIsRedirected(lp))
    7885             :             {

    7890             :             /*

    7893             :              * tuple headers get examined for an htid that leads us to an
    7894             :              * LP_DEAD item.  This is okay because the earlier pruning
    7895             :              * operation that made the line pointer LP_DEAD in the first place
    7896             :              * must have considered the original tuple header as part of
    7897             :              * generating its own snapshotConflictHorizon value.
    7898             :              *
    7899             :              * Relying on XLOG_HEAP2_PRUNE records like this is the same
    7900             :              * strategy that index vacuuming uses in all cases.  Index VACUUM
    7901             :              * WAL records don't even have a snapshotConflictHorizon field of
    7902             :              * their own for this reason.
    7903             :              */
    7904      542002 :             if (!ItemIdIsNormal(lp))
    7905      341284 :                 break;
    7906             : 
    7907      200718 :             htup = (HeapTupleHeader) PageGetItem(page, lp);
    7908             : 
    7909             :             /*
    7910             :              * Check the tuple XMIN against prior XMAX, if any

    7912      221632 :             if (TransactionIdIsValid(priorXmax) &&

    7917             :                                                   &snapshotConflictHorizon);
    7918             : 
    7919             :             /*
    7920             :              * If the tuple is not HOT-updated, then we are at the end of this
    7921             :              * HOT-chain.  No need to visit later tuples from the same update
    7922             :              * chain (they get their own index entries) -- just move on to
    7923             :              * next htid from index AM caller.

    7925      200718 :             if (!HeapTupleHeaderIsHotUpdated(htup))
    7926             :                 break;
    7927             :

    7929       20914 :             Assert(ItemPointerGetBlockNumber(&htup->t_ctid) == blkno);
    7930       20914 :             offnum = ItemPointerGetOffsetNumber(&htup->t_ctid);

    7935      521088 :         finalndeltids = i + 1;

    7939             :

    7942             :      * is not just a minor optimization.  Final deltids array size might be
    7943             :      * zero for a bottom-up caller.  Index AM is explicitly allowed to rely on
    7944             :      * ndeltids being zero in all cases with zero total deletable entries.
    7945             :      */

    7951             : 
    7952             : /*
    7953             :  * Specialized inlineable comparison function for index_delete_sort()
    7954             :  */
    7955             : static inline int
    7956    22268048 : index_delete_sort_cmp(TM_IndexDelete *deltid1, TM_IndexDelete *deltid2)
    7957             : {
    7958    22268048 :     ItemPointer tid1 = &deltid1->tid;
    7959    22268048 :     ItemPointer tid2 = &deltid2->tid;
    7960             : 
    7961             :     {
    7962    22268048 :         BlockNumber blk1 = ItemPointerGetBlockNumber(tid1);
    7963    22268048 :         BlockNumber blk2 = ItemPointerGetBlockNumber(tid2);
    7964             : 
    7965    22268048 :         if (blk1 != blk2)
    7966     9032504 :             return (blk1 < blk2) ? -1 : 1;
    7967             :     }
    7968             :     {
    7969    13235544 :         OffsetNumber pos1 = ItemPointerGetOffsetNumber(tid1);
    7970    13235544 :         OffsetNumber pos2 = ItemPointerGetOffsetNumber(tid2);
    7971             : 
    7972    13235544 :         if (pos1 != pos2)
    7973    13235544 :             return (pos1 < pos2) ? -1 : 1;
    7974             :     }
    7975             : 
    7976           0 :     Assert(false);
    7977             : 
    7978             :     return 0;
    7979             : }
    7980             : 
    7981             : /*
    7982             :  * Sort deltids array from delstate by TID.  This prepares it for further
    7983             :  * processing by heap_index_delete_tuples().
    7984             :  *
    7985             :  * This operation becomes a noticeable consumer of CPU cycles with some
    7986             :  * workloads, so we go to the trouble of specialization/micro optimization.
    7987             :  * We use shellsort for this because it's easy to specialize, compiles to
    7988             :  * relatively few instructions, and is adaptive to presorted inputs/subsets
    7989             :  * (which are typical here).
    7990             :  */
    7991             : static void
    7992        9738 : index_delete_sort(TM_IndexDeleteOp *delstate)
    7993             : {
    7994        9738 :     TM_IndexDelete *deltids = delstate->deltids;
    7995        9738 :     int         ndeltids = delstate->ndeltids;
    7996        9738 :     int         low = 0;
    7997             : 
    7998             :     /*
    7999             :      * Shellsort gap sequence (taken from Sedgewick-Incerpi paper).
    8000             :      *
    8001             :      * This implementation is fast with array sizes up to ~4500.  This covers
    8002             :      * all supported BLCKSZ values.
    8003             :      */
    8004        9738 :     const int   gaps[9] = {1968, 861, 336, 112, 48, 21, 7, 3, 1};
    8005             : 
    8006             :     /* Think carefully before changing anything here -- keep swaps cheap */
    8007             :     StaticAssertDecl(sizeof(TM_IndexDelete) <= 8,
    8008             :                      "element size exceeds 8 bytes");
    8009             : 
    8010       97380 :     for (int g = 0; g < lengthof(gaps); g++)
    8011             :     {
    8012    13355046 :         for (int hi = gaps[g], i = low + hi; i < ndeltids; i++)
    8013             :         {
    8014    13267404 :             TM_IndexDelete d = deltids[i];
    8015    13267404 :             int         j = i;
    8016             : 
    8017    22884680 :             while (j >= hi && index_delete_sort_cmp(&deltids[j - hi], &d) >= 0)
    8018             :             {
    8019     9617276 :                 deltids[j] = deltids[j - hi];
    8020     9617276 :                 j -= hi;
    8021             :             }
    8022    13267404 :             deltids[j] = d;
    8023             :         }
    8024             :     }
    8025        9738 : }
    8026             : 
    8027             : /*
    8028             :  * Returns how many blocks should be considered favorable/contiguous for a
    8029             :  * bottom-up index deletion pass.  This is a number of heap blocks that starts
    8030             :  * from and includes the first block in line.
    8031             :  *
    8032             :  * There is always at least one favorable block during bottom-up index
    8033             :  * deletion.  In the worst case (i.e. with totally random heap blocks) the
    8034             :  * first block in line (the only favorable block) can be thought of as a
    8035             :  * degenerate array of contiguous blocks that consists of a single block.
    8036             :  * heap_index_delete_tuples() will expect this.
    8037             :  *
    8038             :  * Caller passes blockgroups, a description of the final order that deltids
    8039             :  * will be sorted in for heap_index_delete_tuples() bottom-up index deletion
    8040             :  * processing.  Note that deltids need not actually be sorted just yet (caller
    8041             :  * only passes deltids to us so that we can interpret blockgroups).
    8042             :  *
    8043             :  * You might guess that the existence of contiguous blocks cannot matter much,
    8044             :  * since in general the main factor that determines which blocks we visit is
    8045             :  * the number of promising TIDs, which is a fixed hint from the index AM.
    8046             :  * We're not really targeting the general case, though -- the actual goal is
    8047             :  * to adapt our behavior to a wide variety of naturally occurring conditions.
    8048             :  * The effects of most of the heuristics we apply are only noticeable in the
    8049             :  * aggregate, over time and across many _related_ bottom-up index deletion
    8050             :  * passes.
    8051             :  *
    8052             :  * Deeming certain blocks favorable allows heapam to recognize and adapt to
    8053             :  * workloads where heap blocks visited during bottom-up index deletion can be
    8054             :  * accessed contiguously, in the sense that each newly visited block is the
    8055             :  * neighbor of the block that bottom-up deletion just finished processing (or
    8056             :  * close enough to it).  It will likely be cheaper to access more favorable
    8057             :  * blocks sooner rather than later (e.g. in this pass, not across a series of
    8058             :  * related bottom-up passes).  Either way it is probably only a matter of time
    8059             :  * (or a matter of further correlated version churn) before all blocks that
    8060             :  * appear together as a single large batch of favorable blocks get accessed by
    8061             :  * _some_ bottom-up pass.  Large batches of favorable blocks tend to either
    8062             :  * appear almost constantly or not even once (it all depends on per-index
    8063             :  * workload characteristics).
    8064             :  *
    8065             :  * Note that the blockgroups sort order applies a power-of-two bucketing
    8066             :  * scheme that creates opportunities for contiguous groups of blocks to get
    8067             :  * batched together, at least with workloads that are naturally amenable to
    8068             :  * being driven by heap block locality.  This doesn't just enhance the spatial
    8069             :  * locality of bottom-up heap block processing in the obvious way.  It also
    8070             :  * enables temporal locality of access, since sorting by heap block number
    8071             :  * naturally tends to make the bottom-up processing order deterministic.
    8072             :  *
    8073             :  * Consider the following example to get a sense of how temporal locality
    8074             :  * might matter: There is a heap relation with several indexes, each of which
    8075             :  * is low to medium cardinality.  It is subject to constant non-HOT updates.
    8076             :  * The updates are skewed (in one part of the primary key, perhaps).  None of
    8077             :  * the indexes are logically modified by the UPDATE statements (if they were
    8078             :  * then bottom-up index deletion would not be triggered in the first place).
    8079             :  * Naturally, each new round of index tuples (for each heap tuple that gets a
    8080             :  * heap_update() call) will have the same heap TID in each and every index.
    8081             :  * Since these indexes are low cardinality and never get logically modified,
    8082             :  * heapam processing during bottom-up deletion passes will access heap blocks
    8083             :  * in approximately sequential order.  Temporal locality of access occurs due
    8084             :  * to bottom-up deletion passes behaving very similarly across each of the
    8085             :  * indexes at any given moment.  This keeps the number of buffer misses needed
    8086             :  * to visit heap blocks to a minimum.
    8087             :  */
    8088             : static int
    8089        3246 : bottomup_nblocksfavorable(IndexDeleteCounts *blockgroups, int nblockgroups,
    8090             :                           TM_IndexDelete *deltids)
    8091             : {
    8092        3246 :     int64       lastblock = -1;
    8093        3246 :     int         nblocksfavorable = 0;
    8094             : 
    8095        3246 :     Assert(nblockgroups >= 1);
    8096        3246 :     Assert(nblockgroups <= BOTTOMUP_MAX_NBLOCKS);
    8097             : 
    8098             :     /*
    8099             :      * We tolerate heap blocks that will be accessed only slightly out of
    8100             :      * physical order.  Small blips occur when a pair of almost-contiguous
    8101             :      * blocks happen to fall into different buckets (perhaps due only to a
    8102             :      * small difference in npromisingtids that the bucketing scheme didn't
    8103             :      * quite manage to ignore).  We effectively ignore these blips by applying
    8104             :      * a small tolerance.  The precise tolerance we use is a little arbitrary,
    8105             :      * but it works well enough in practice.
    8106             :      */
    8107        9762 :     for (int b = 0; b < nblockgroups; b++)
    8108             :     {
    8109        9406 :         IndexDeleteCounts *group = blockgroups + b;
    8110        9406 :         TM_IndexDelete *firstdtid = deltids + group->ifirsttid;
    8111        9406 :         BlockNumber block = ItemPointerGetBlockNumber(&firstdtid->tid);
    8112             : 
    8113        9406 :         if (lastblock != -1 &&
    8114        6160 :             ((int64) block < lastblock - BOTTOMUP_TOLERANCE_NBLOCKS ||
    8115        5168 :              (int64) block > lastblock + BOTTOMUP_TOLERANCE_NBLOCKS))
    8116             :             break;
    8117             : 
    8118        6516 :         nblocksfavorable++;
    8119        6516 :         lastblock = block;
    8120             :     }
    8121             : 
    8122             :     /* Always indicate that there is at least 1 favorable block */
    8123        3246 :     Assert(nblocksfavorable >= 1);
    8124             : 
    8125        3246 :     return nblocksfavorable;
    8126             : }
    8127             : 
    8128             : /*
    8129             :  * qsort comparison function for bottomup_sort_and_shrink()
    8130             :  */
    8131             : static int
    8132      344110 : bottomup_sort_and_shrink_cmp(const void *arg1, const void *arg2)
    8133             : {
    8134      344110 :     const IndexDeleteCounts *group1 = (const IndexDeleteCounts *) arg1;
    8135      344110 :     const IndexDeleteCounts *group2 = (const IndexDeleteCounts *) arg2;
    8136             : 
    8137             :     /*
    8138             :      * Most significant field is npromisingtids (which we invert the order of
    8139             :      * so as to sort in desc order).
    8140             :      *
    8141             :      * Caller should have already normalized npromisingtids fields into
    8142             :      * power-of-two values (buckets).
    8143             :      */
    8144      344110 :     if (group1->npromisingtids > group2->npromisingtids)
    8145       14930 :         return -1;
    8146      329180 :     if (group1->npromisingtids < group2->npromisingtids)
    8147       17524 :         return 1;
    8148             : 
    8149             :     /*
    8150             :      * Tiebreak: desc ntids sort order.
    8151             :      *
    8152             :      * We cannot expect power-of-two values for ntids fields.  We should
    8153             :      * behave as if they were already rounded up for us instead.
    8154             :      */
    8155      311656 :     if (group1->ntids != group2->ntids)
    8156             :     {
    8157      219476 :         uint32      ntids1 = pg_nextpower2_32((uint32) group1->ntids);
    8158      219476 :         uint32      ntids2 = pg_nextpower2_32((uint32) group2->ntids);
    8159             : 
    8160      219476 :         if (ntids1 > ntids2)
    8161       31536 :             return -1;
    8162      187940 :         if (ntids1 < ntids2)
    8163       38580 :             return 1;
    8164             :     }
    8165             : 
    8166             :     /*
    8167             :      * Tiebreak: asc offset-into-deltids-for-block (offset to first TID for
    8168             :      * block in deltids array) order.
    8169             :      *
    8170             :      * This is equivalent to sorting in ascending heap block number order
    8171             :      * (among otherwise equal subsets of the array).  This approach allows us
    8172             :      * to avoid accessing the out-of-line TID.  (We rely on the assumption
    8173             :      * that the deltids array was sorted in ascending heap TID order when
    8174             :      * these offsets to the first TID from each heap block group were formed.)
    8175             :      */
    8176      241540 :     if (group1->ifirsttid > group2->ifirsttid)
    8177      117992 :         return 1;
    8178      123548 :     if (group1->ifirsttid < group2->ifirsttid)
    8179      123548 :         return -1;
    8180             : 
    8181           0 :     pg_unreachable();
    8182             : 
    8183             :     return 0;
    8184             : }
    8185             : 
    8186             : /*
    8187             :  * heap_index_delete_tuples() helper function for bottom-up deletion callers.
    8188             :  *
    8189             :  * Sorts deltids array in the order needed for useful processing by bottom-up
    8190             :  * deletion.  The array should already be sorted in TID order when we're
    8191             :  * called.  The sort process groups heap TIDs from deltids into heap block
    8192             :  * groupings.  Earlier/more-promising groups/blocks are usually those that are
    8193             :  * known to have the most "promising" TIDs.
    8194             :  *
    8195             :  * Sets new size of deltids array (ndeltids) in state.  deltids will only have
    8196             :  * TIDs from the BOTTOMUP_MAX_NBLOCKS most promising heap blocks when we
    8197             :  * return.  This often means that deltids will be shrunk to a small fraction
    8198             :  * of its original size (we eliminate many heap blocks from consideration for
    8199             :  * caller up front).
    8200             :  *
    8201             :  * Returns the number of "favorable" blocks.  See bottomup_nblocksfavorable()
    8202             :  * for a definition and full details.
    8203             :  */
    8204             : static int
    8205        3246 : bottomup_sort_and_shrink(TM_IndexDeleteOp *delstate)
    8206             : {
    8207             :     IndexDeleteCounts *blockgroups;
    8208             :     TM_IndexDelete *reordereddeltids;
    8209        3246 :     BlockNumber curblock = InvalidBlockNumber;
    8210        3246 :     int         nblockgroups = 0;
    8211        3246 :     int         ncopied = 0;
    8212        3246 :     int         nblocksfavorable = 0;
    8213             : 
    8214        3246 :     Assert(delstate->bottomup);
    8215        3246 :     Assert(delstate->ndeltids > 0);
    8216             : 
    8217             :     /* Calculate per-heap-block count of TIDs */
    8218        3246 :     blockgroups = palloc(sizeof(IndexDeleteCounts) * delstate->ndeltids);
    8219     1643280 :     for (int i = 0; i < delstate->ndeltids; i++)
    8220             :     {
    8221     1640034 :         TM_IndexDelete *ideltid = &delstate->deltids[i];
    8222     1640034 :         TM_IndexStatus *istatus = delstate->status + ideltid->id;
    8223     1640034 :         ItemPointer htid = &ideltid->tid;
    8224     1640034 :         bool        promising = istatus->promising;
    8225             : 
    8226     1640034 :         if (curblock != ItemPointerGetBlockNumber(htid))
    8227             :         {
    8228             :             /* New block group */
    8229       64438 :             nblockgroups++;
    8230             : 
    8231       64438 :             Assert(curblock < ItemPointerGetBlockNumber(htid) ||
    8232             :                    !BlockNumberIsValid(curblock));
    8233             : 
    8234       64438 :             curblock = ItemPointerGetBlockNumber(htid);
    8235       64438 :             blockgroups[nblockgroups - 1].ifirsttid = i;
    8236       64438 :             blockgroups[nblockgroups - 1].ntids = 1;
    8237       64438 :             blockgroups[nblockgroups - 1].npromisingtids = 0;
    8238             :         }
    8239             :         else
    8240             :         {
    8241     1575596 :             blockgroups[nblockgroups - 1].ntids++;
    8242             :         }
    8243             : 
    8244     1640034 :         if (promising)
    8245      197452 :             blockgroups[nblockgroups - 1].npromisingtids++;
    8246             :     }
    8247             : 
    8248             :     /*
    8249             :      * We're about ready to sort block groups to determine the optimal order
    8250             :      * for visiting heap blocks.  But before we do, round the number of
    8251             :      * promising tuples for each block group up to the next power-of-two,
    8252             :      * unless it is very low (less than 4), in which case we round up to 4.
    8253             :      * npromisingtids is far too noisy to trust when choosing between a pair
    8254             :      * of block groups that both have very low values.
    8255             :      *
    8256             :      * This scheme divides heap blocks/block groups into buckets.  Each bucket
    8257             :      * contains blocks that have _approximately_ the same number of promising
    8258             :      * TIDs as each other.  The goal is to ignore relatively small differences
    8259             :      * in the total number of promising entries, so that the whole process can
    8260             :      * give a little weight to heapam factors (like heap block locality)
    8261             :      * instead.  This isn't a trade-off, really -- we have nothing to lose. It
    8262             :      * would be foolish to interpret small differences in npromisingtids
    8263             :      * values as anything more than noise.
    8264             :      *
    8265             :      * We tiebreak on nhtids when sorting block group subsets that have the
    8266             :      * same npromisingtids, but this has the same issues as npromisingtids,
    8267             :      * and so nhtids is subject to the same power-of-two bucketing scheme. The
    8268             :      * only reason that we don't fix nhtids in the same way here too is that
    8269             :      * we'll need accurate nhtids values after the sort.  We handle nhtids
    8270             :      * bucketization dynamically instead (in the sort comparator).
    8271             :      *
    8272             :      * See bottomup_nblocksfavorable() for a full explanation of when and how
    8273             :      * heap locality/favorable blocks can significantly influence when and how
    8274             :      * heap blocks are accessed.
    8275             :      */
    8276       67684 :     for (int b = 0; b < nblockgroups; b++)
    8277             :     {
    8278       64438 :         IndexDeleteCounts *group = blockgroups + b;
    8279             : 
    8280             :         /* Better off falling back on nhtids with low npromisingtids */
    8281       64438 :         if (group->npromisingtids <= 4)
    8282       55518 :             group->npromisingtids = 4;
    8283             :         else
    8284        8920 :             group->npromisingtids =
    8285        8920 :                 pg_nextpower2_32((uint32) group->npromisingtids);
    8286             :     }
    8287             : 
    8288             :     /* Sort groups and rearrange caller's deltids array */
    8289        3246 :     qsort(blockgroups, nblockgroups, sizeof(IndexDeleteCounts),
    8290             :           bottomup_sort_and_shrink_cmp);
    8291        3246 :     reordereddeltids = palloc(delstate->ndeltids * sizeof(TM_IndexDelete));
    8292             : 
    8293        3246 :     nblockgroups = Min(BOTTOMUP_MAX_NBLOCKS, nblockgroups);
    8294             :     /* Determine number of favorable blocks at the start of final deltids */
    8295        3246 :     nblocksfavorable = bottomup_nblocksfavorable(blockgroups, nblockgroups,
    8296             :                                                  delstate->deltids);
    8297             : 
    8298       21494 :     for (int b = 0; b < nblockgroups; b++)
    8299             :     {
    8300       18248 :         IndexDeleteCounts *group = blockgroups + b;
    8301       18248 :         TM_IndexDelete *firstdtid = delstate->deltids + group->ifirsttid;
    8302             : 
    8303       18248 :         memcpy(reordereddeltids + ncopied, firstdtid,
    8304       18248 :                sizeof(TM_IndexDelete) * group->ntids);
    8305       18248 :         ncopied += group->ntids;
    8306             :     }
    8307             : 
    8308             :     /* Copy final grouped and sorted TIDs back into start of caller's array */
    8309        3246 :     memcpy(delstate->deltids, reordereddeltids,
    8310             :            sizeof(TM_IndexDelete) * ncopied);
    8311        3246 :     delstate->ndeltids = ncopied;
    8312             : 
    8313        3246 :     pfree(reordereddeltids);
    8314        3246 :     pfree(blockgroups);
    8315             : 
    8316        3246 :     return nblocksfavorable;
    8317             : }
    8318             : 
    8319             : /*
    8320             :  * Perform XLogInsert for a heap-visible operation.  'block' is the block
    8321             :  * being marked all-visible, and vm_buffer is the buffer containing the
    8322             :  * corresponding visibility map block.  Both should have already been modified
    8323             :  * and dirtied.
    8324             :  *
    8325             :  * snapshotConflictHorizon comes from the largest xmin on the page being
    8326             :  * marked all-visible.  REDO routine uses it to generate recovery conflicts.
    8327             :  *
    8328             :  * If checksums or wal_log_hints are enabled, we may also generate a full-page
    8329             :  * image of heap_buffer. Otherwise, we optimize away the FPI (by specifying
    8330             :  * REGBUF_NO_IMAGE for the heap buffer), in which case the caller should *not*
    8331             :  * update the heap page's LSN.
    8332             :  */
    8333             : XLogRecPtr
    8334       56474 : log_heap_visible(Relation rel, Buffer heap_buffer, Buffer vm_buffer,
    8335             :                  TransactionId snapshotConflictHorizon, uint8 vmflags)
    8336             : {
    8337             :     xl_heap_visible xlrec;
    8338             :     XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    8339             :     uint8       flags;
    8340             : 
    8341       56474 :     Assert(BufferIsValid(heap_buffer));
    8342       56474 :     Assert(BufferIsValid(vm_buffer));
    8343             : 
    8344       56474 :     xlrec.snapshotConflictHorizon = snapshotConflictHorizon;
    8345       56474 :     xlrec.flags = vmflags;
    8346       56474 :     if (RelationIsAccessibleInLogicalDecoding(rel))
    8347         256 :         xlrec.flags |= VISIBILITYMAP_XLOG_CATALOG_REL;
    8348       56474 :     XLogBeginInsert();
    8349       56474 :     XLogRegisterData((char *) &xlrec, SizeOfHeapVisible);
    8350             : 
    8351       56474 :     XLogRegisterBuffer(0, vm_buffer, 0);
    8352             : 
    8353       56474 :     flags = REGBUF_STANDARD;
    8354       56474 :     if (!XLogHintBitIsNeeded())
    8355       44726 :         flags |= REGBUF_NO_IMAGE;
    8356       56474 :     XLogRegisterBuffer(1, heap_buffer, flags);
    8357             : 
    8358       56474 :     recptr = XLogInsert(RM_HEAP2_ID, XLOG_HEAP2_VISIBLE);
    8359             : 
    8360       56474 :     return recptr;
    8361             : }
    8362             : 
    8363             : /*
    8364             :  * Perform XLogInsert for a heap-update operation.  Caller must already
    8365             :  * have modified the buffer(s) and marked them dirty.
    8366             :  */
    8367             : static XLogRecPtr
    8368      508488 : log_heap_update(Relation reln, Buffer oldbuf,
    8369             :                 Buffer newbuf, HeapTuple oldtup, HeapTuple newtup,
    8370             :                 HeapTuple old_key_tuple,
    8371             :                 bool all_visible_cleared, bool new_all_visible_cleared)
    8372             : {
    8373             :     xl_heap_update xlrec;
    8374             :     xl_heap_header xlhdr;
    8375             :     xl_heap_header xlhdr_idx;
    8376             :     uint8       info;
    8377             :     uint16      prefix_suffix[2];
    8378      508488 :     uint16      prefixlen = 0,
    8379      508488 :                 suffixlen = 0;
    8380             :     XLogRecPtr  recptr;
    8381      508488 :     Page        page = BufferGetPage(newbuf);
    8382      508488 :     bool        need_tuple_data = RelationIsLogicallyLogged(reln);
    8383             :     bool        init;
    8384             :     int         bufflags;
    8385             : 
    8386             :     /* Caller should not call me on a non-WAL-logged relation */
    8387      508488 :     Assert(RelationNeedsWAL(reln));
    8388             : 
    8389      508488 :     XLogBeginInsert();
    8390             : 
    8391      508488 :     if (HeapTupleIsHeapOnly(newtup))
    8392      238324 :         info = XLOG_HEAP_HOT_UPDATE;
    8393             :     else
    8394      270164 :         info = XLOG_HEAP_UPDATE;
    8395             : 
    8396             :     /*
    8397             :      * If the old and new tuple are on the same page, we only need to log the
    8398             :      * parts of the new tuple that were changed.  That saves on the amount of
    8399             :      * WAL we need to write.  Currently, we just count any unchanged bytes in
    8400             :      * the beginning and end of the tuple.  That's quick to check, and
    8401             :      * perfectly covers the common case that only one field is updated.
    8402             :      *
    8403             :      * We could do this even if the old and new tuple are on different pages,
    8404             :      * but only if we don't make a full-page image of the old page, which is
    8405             :      * difficult to know in advance.  Also, if the old tuple is corrupt for
    8406             :      * some reason, it would allow the corruption to propagate the new page,
    8407             :      * so it seems best to avoid.  Under the general assumption that most
    8408             :      * updates tend to create the new tuple version on the same page, there
    8409             :      * isn't much to be gained by doing this across pages anyway.
    8410             :      *
    8411             :      * Skip this if we're taking a full-page image of the new page, as we
    8412             :      * don't include the new tuple in the WAL record in that case.  Also
    8413             :      * disable if wal_level='logical', as logical decoding needs to be able to
    8414             :      * read the new tuple in whole from the WAL record alone.
    8415             :      */
    8416      508488 :     if (oldbuf == newbuf && !need_tuple_data &&
    8417      233154 :         !XLogCheckBufferNeedsBackup(newbuf))
    8418             :     {
    8419      232364 :         char       *oldp = (char *) oldtup->t_data + oldtup->t_data->t_hoff;

    8422      232364 :         int         newlen = newtup->t_len - newtup->t_data->t_hoff;
    8423             : 
    8424             :         /* Check for common prefix between old and new tuple */
    8425    16969532 :         for (prefixlen = 0; prefixlen < Min(oldlen, newlen); prefixlen++)
    8426             :         {
    8427    16929838 :             if (newp[prefixlen] != oldp[prefixlen])
    8428      192670 :                 break;

    8430             :

    8573             :     }
    8574             : 
    8575             :     /* filtering by origin on a row level is much more efficient */
    8576      508488 :     XLogSetRecordFlags(XLOG_INCLUDE_ORIGIN);
    8577             : 
    8578      508488 :     recptr = XLogInsert(RM_HEAP_ID, info);
    8579             : 
    8580      508488 :     return recptr;
    8581             : }

    8583             : /*

    8657             : /*
    8658             :  * Build a heap tuple representing the configured REPLICA IDENTITY to represent
    8659             :  * the old tuple in an UPDATE or DELETE.
    8660             :  *
    8661             :  * Returns NULL if there's no need to log an identity or if there's no suitable
    8662             :  * key defined.
    8663             :  *
    8664             :  * Pass key_required true if any replica identity columns changed value, or if
    8665             :  * any of them have any external data.  Delete must always pass true.
    8666             :  *
    8667             :  * *copy is set to true if the returned tuple is a modified copy rather than
    8668             :  * the same tuple that was passed in.
    8669             :  */
    8670             : static HeapTuple
    8671     3223942 : ExtractReplicaIdentity(Relation relation, HeapTuple tp, bool key_required,
    8672             :                        bool *copy)
    8673             : {
    8674     3223942 :     TupleDesc   desc = RelationGetDescr(relation);

    8680             :

    8682             : 
    8683     3223942 :     if (!RelationIsLogicallyLogged(relation))
    8684     3023422 :         return NULL;
    8685             :

    8693             :          * toasted columns. If so, force them to be inlined.

    8775             : 
    8776             :     /*
    8777             :      * We're about to remove tuples. In Hot Standby mode, ensure that there's
    8778             :      * no queries running for which the removed tuples are still visible.
    8779             :      */

    8781       12214 :         ResolveRecoveryConflictWithSnapshot(xlrec->snapshotConflictHorizon,
    8782       12214 :                                             xlrec->isCatalogRel,
    8783             :                                             rlocator);
    8784             : 
    8785             :     /*
    8786             :      * If we have a full-page image, restore it (using a cleanup lock) and
    8787             :      * we're done.
    8788             :      */
    8789       12988 :     action = XLogReadBufferForRedoExtended(record, 0, RBM_NORMAL, true,
    8790             :                                            &buffer);
    8791       12988 :     if (action == BLK_NEEDS_REDO)
    8792             :     {
    8793       11612 :         Page        page = (Page) BufferGetPage(buffer);
    8794             :         OffsetNumber *end;

    8816             :                                 nowdead, ndead,
    8817             :                                 nowunused, nunused);
    8818             : 
    8819             :         /*
    8820             :          * Note: we don't worry about updating the page's prunability hints.
    8821             :          * At worst this will cause an extra prune cycle to occur soon.
    8822             :          */
    8823             : 
    8824       11612 :         PageSetLSN(page, lsn);
    8825       11612 :         MarkBufferDirty(buffer);
    8826             :     }
    8827             : 
    8828       12988 :     if (BufferIsValid(buffer))
    8829             :     {
    8830       12988 :         Size        freespace = PageGetHeapFreeSpace(BufferGetPage(buffer));
    8831             : 
    8832       12988 :         UnlockReleaseBuffer(buffer);
    8833             : 
    8834             :         /*
    8835             :          * After pruning records from a page, it's useful to update the FSM
    8836             :          * about it, as it may cause the page become target for insertions
    8837             :          * later even if vacuum decides not to visit it (which is possible if
    8838             :          * gets marked all-visible.)

    8840             :          * Do this regardless of a full-page image being applied, since the
    8841             :          * FSM data is not in the page anyway.

    8918             : 
    8919             : /*
    8920             :  * Replay XLOG_HEAP2_VISIBLE record.
    8921             :  *
    8922             :  * The critical integrity requirement here is that we must never end up with
    8923             :  * a situation where the visibility map bit is set, and the page-level
    8924             :  * PD_ALL_VISIBLE bit is clear.  If that were to occur, then a subsequent
    8925             :  * page modification would fail to clear the visibility map bit.
    8926             :  */
    8927             : static void
    8928        7224 : heap_xlog_visible(XLogReaderState *record)
    8929             : {
    8930        7224 :     XLogRecPtr  lsn = record->EndRecPtr;
    8931        7224 :     xl_heap_visible *xlrec = (xl_heap_visible *) XLogRecGetData(record);
    8932        7224 :     Buffer      vmbuffer = InvalidBuffer;
    8933             :     Buffer      buffer;
    8934             :     Page        page;
    8935             :     RelFileLocator rlocator;
    8936             :     BlockNumber blkno;
    8937             :     XLogRedoAction action;
    8938             : 
    8939        7224 :     Assert((xlrec->flags & VISIBILITYMAP_XLOG_VALID_BITS) == xlrec->flags);
    8940             : 
    8941        7224 :     XLogRecGetBlockTag(record, 1, &rlocator, NULL, &blkno);
    8942             : 
    8943             :     /*
    8944             :      * If there are any Hot Standby transactions running that have an xmin
    8945             :      * horizon old enough that this page isn't all-visible for them, they
    8946             :      * might incorrectly decide that an index-only scan can skip a heap fetch.
    8947             :      *
    8948             :      * NB: It might be better to throw some kind of "soft" conflict here that
    8949             :      * forces any index-only scan that is in flight to perform heap fetches,
    8950             :      * rather than killing the transaction outright.
    8951             :      */
    8952        7224 :     if (InHotStandby)
    8953        6876 :         ResolveRecoveryConflictWithSnapshot(xlrec->snapshotConflictHorizon,
    8954        6876 :                                             xlrec->flags & VISIBILITYMAP_XLOG_CATALOG_REL,
    8955             :                                             rlocator);
    8956             : 
    8957             :     /*
    8958             :      * Read the heap page, if it still exists. If the heap file has dropped or
    8959             :      * truncated later in recovery, we don't need to update the page, but we'd
    8960             :      * better still update the visibility map.
    8961             :      */
    8962        7224 :     action = XLogReadBufferForRedo(record, 1, &buffer);
    8963        7224 :     if (action == BLK_NEEDS_REDO)
    8964             :     {
    8965             :         /*
    8966             :          * We don't bump the LSN of the heap page when setting the visibility
    8967             :          * map bit (unless checksums or wal_hint_bits is enabled, in which
    8968             :          * case we must). This exposes us to torn page hazards, but since
    8969             :          * we're not inspecting the existing page contents in any way, we
    8970             :          * don't care.
    8971             :          */
    8972        5144 :         page = BufferGetPage(buffer);
    8973             : 
    8974        5144 :         PageSetAllVisible(page);
    8975             : 
    8976        5144 :         if (XLogHintBitIsNeeded())
    8977        4964 :             PageSetLSN(page, lsn);
    8978             : 
    8979        5144 :         MarkBufferDirty(buffer);
    8980             :     }
    8981             :     else if (action == BLK_RESTORED)
    8982             :     {
    8983             :         /*
    8984             :          * If heap block was backed up, we already restored it and there's
    8985             :          * nothing more to do. (This can only happen with checksums or
    8986             :          * wal_log_hints enabled.)
    8987             :          */
    8988             :     }
    8989             : 
    8990        7224 :     if (BufferIsValid(buffer))
    8991             :     {
    8992        7134 :         Size        space = PageGetFreeSpace(BufferGetPage(buffer));
    8993             : 
    8994        7134 :         UnlockReleaseBuffer(buffer);
    8995             : 
    8996             :         /*
    8997             :          * Since FSM is not WAL-logged and only updated heuristically, it
    8998             :          * easily becomes stale in standbys.  If the standby is later promoted
    8999             :          * and runs VACUUM, it will skip updating individual free space
    9000             :          * figures for pages that became all-visible (or all-frozen, depending
    9001             :          * on the vacuum mode,) which is troublesome when FreeSpaceMapVacuum
    9002             :          * propagates too optimistic free space values to upper FSM layers;
    9003             :          * later inserters try to use such pages only to find out that they
    9004             :          * are unusable.  This can cause long stalls when there are many such
    9005             :          * pages.
    9006             :          *
    9007             :          * Forestall those problems by updating FSM's idea about a page that
    9008             :          * is becoming all-visible or all-frozen.
    9009             :          *
    9010             :          * Do this regardless of a full-page image being applied, since the
    9011             :          * FSM data is not in the page anyway.
    9012             :          */
    9013        7134 :         if (xlrec->flags & VISIBILITYMAP_VALID_BITS)
    9014        7134 :             XLogRecordPageWithFreeSpace(rlocator, blkno, space);
    9015             :     }
    9016             : 
    9017             :     /*
    9018             :      * Even if we skipped the heap page update due to the LSN interlock, it's
    9019             :      * still safe to update the visibility map.  Any WAL record that clears
    9020             :      * the visibility map bit does so before checking the page LSN, so any
    9021             :      * bits that need to be cleared will still be cleared.
    9022             :      */
    9023        7224 :     if (XLogReadBufferForRedoExtended(record, 0, RBM_ZERO_ON_ERROR, false,
    9024             :                                       &vmbuffer) == BLK_NEEDS_REDO)
    9025             :     {
    9026        6814 :         Page        vmpage = BufferGetPage(vmbuffer);
    9027             :         Relation    reln;
    9028             :         uint8       vmbits;
    9029             : 
    9030             :         /* initialize the page if it was read as zeros */
    9031        6814 :         if (PageIsNew(vmpage))
    9032           0 :             PageInit(vmpage, BLCKSZ, 0);
    9033             : 
    9034             :         /* remove VISIBILITYMAP_XLOG_* */
    9035        6814 :         vmbits = xlrec->flags & VISIBILITYMAP_VALID_BITS;
    9036             : 
    9037             :         /*
    9038             :          * XLogReadBufferForRedoExtended locked the buffer. But
    9039             :          * visibilitymap_set will handle locking itself.
    9040             :          */
    9041        6814 :         LockBuffer(vmbuffer, BUFFER_LOCK_UNLOCK);
    9042             : 
    9043        6814 :         reln = CreateFakeRelcacheEntry(rlocator);
    9044        6814 :         visibilitymap_pin(reln, blkno, &vmbuffer);
    9045             : 
    9046        6814 :         visibilitymap_set(reln, blkno, InvalidBuffer, lsn, vmbuffer,
    9047             :                           xlrec->snapshotConflictHorizon, vmbits);
    9048             : 
    9049        6814 :         ReleaseBuffer(vmbuffer);
    9050        6814 :         FreeFakeRelcacheEntry(reln);
    9051             :     }
    9052         410 :     else if (BufferIsValid(vmbuffer))
    9053         410 :         UnlockReleaseBuffer(vmbuffer);
    9054        7224 : }
    9055             : 
    9056             : /*
    9057             :  * Replay XLOG_HEAP2_FREEZE_PAGE records
    9058             :  */
    9059             : static void
    9060         236 : heap_xlog_freeze_page(XLogReaderState *record)
    9061             : {
    9062         236 :     XLogRecPtr  lsn = record->EndRecPtr;
    9063         236 :     xl_heap_freeze_page *xlrec = (xl_heap_freeze_page *) XLogRecGetData(record);
    9064             :     Buffer      buffer;
    9065             : 
    9066             :     /*
    9067             :      * In Hot Standby mode, ensure that there's no queries running which still
    9068             :      * consider the frozen xids as running.
    9069             :      */
    9070         236 :     if (InHotStandby)
    9071             :     {
    9072             :         RelFileLocator rlocator;
    9073             :

    9124             : /*
    9125             :  * Given an "infobits" field from an XLog record, set the correct bits in the
    9126             :  * given infomask and infomask2 for the tuple touched by the record.
    9127             :  *
    9128             :  * (This is the reverse of compute_infobits).
    9129             :  */
    9130             : static void
    9131      851668 : fix_infomask_from_infobits(uint8 infobits, uint16 *infomask, uint16 *infomask2)
    9132             : {
    9133      851668 :     *infomask &= ~(HEAP_XMAX_IS_MULTI | HEAP_XMAX_LOCK_ONLY |
    9134             :                    HEAP_XMAX_KEYSHR_LOCK | HEAP_XMAX_EXCL_LOCK);
    9135      851668 :     *infomask2 &= ~HEAP_KEYS_UPDATED;
    9136             : 
    9137      851668 :     if (infobits & XLHL_XMAX_IS_MULTI)
    9138           4 :         *infomask |= HEAP_XMAX_IS_MULTI;
    9139      851668 :     if (infobits & XLHL_XMAX_LOCK_ONLY)
    9140      108140 :         *infomask |= HEAP_XMAX_LOCK_ONLY;
    9141      851668 :     if (infobits & XLHL_XMAX_EXCL_LOCK)
    9142      107550 :         *infomask |= HEAP_XMAX_EXCL_LOCK;
    9143             :     /* note HEAP_XMAX_SHR_LOCK isn't considered here */
    9144      851668 :     if (infobits & XLHL_XMAX_KEYSHR_LOCK)
    9145         612 :         *infomask |= HEAP_XMAX_KEYSHR_LOCK;
    9146             : 
    9147      851668 :     if (infobits & XLHL_KEYS_UPDATED)
    9148      565936 :         *infomask2 |= HEAP_KEYS_UPDATED;
    9149      851668 : }

    9488             : /*
    9489             :  * Handles UPDATE and HOT_UPDATE

    9491             : static void
    9492      180216 : heap_xlog_update(XLogReaderState *record, bool hot_update)
    9493             : {
    9494      180216 :     XLogRecPtr  lsn = record->EndRecPtr;
    9495      180216 :     xl_heap_update *xlrec = (xl_heap_update *) XLogRecGetData(record);

    9498             :     BlockNumber newblk;

    9500             :     Buffer      obuffer,
    9501             :                 nbuffer;
    9502             :     Page        page;
    9503             :     OffsetNumber offnum;
    9504      180216 :     ItemId      lp = NULL;
    9505             :     HeapTupleData oldtup;
    9506             :     HeapTupleHeader htup;
    9507      180216 :     uint16      prefixlen = 0,
    9508      180216 :                 suffixlen = 0;

    9510             :     union
    9511             :     {
    9512             :         HeapTupleHeaderData hdr;
    9513             :         char        data[MaxHeapTupleSize];
    9514             :     }           tbuf;
    9515             :     xl_heap_header xlhdr;
    9516             :     uint32      newlen;
    9517      180216 :     Size        freespace = 0;
    9518             :     XLogRedoAction oldaction;
    9519             :     XLogRedoAction newaction;
    9520             : 
    9521             :     /* initialize to keep the compiler quiet */
    9522      180216 :     oldtup.t_data = NULL;
    9523      180216 :     oldtup.t_len = 0;
    9524             :

    9551             :     /*
    9552             :      * In normal operation, it is important to lock the two pages in
    9553             :      * page-number order, to avoid possible deadlocks against other update
    9554             :      * operations going the other way.  However, during WAL replay there can
    9555             :      * be no other update happening, so we don't need to worry about that. But
    9556             :      * we *do* need to worry that we don't expose an inconsistent state to Hot
    9557             :      * Standby queries --- so the original page can't be unlocked before we've
    9558             :      * added the new tuple to the new page.
    9559             :      */
    9560             :

    9741      180216 :     if (BufferIsValid(obuffer))
    9742      180216 :         UnlockReleaseBuffer(obuffer);
    9743             : 
    9744             :     /*
    9745             :      * If the new page is running low on free space, update the FSM as well.
    9746             :      * Arbitrarily, our definition of "low" is less than 20%. We can't do much
    9747             :      * better than that without knowing the fill-factor for the table.
    9748             :      *
    9749             :      * However, don't update the FSM on HOT updates, because after crash
    9750             :      * recovery, either the old or the new tuple will certainly be dead and
    9751             :      * prunable. After pruning, the page will have roughly as much free space
    9752             :      * as it did before the update, assuming the new tuple is about the same
    9753             :      * size as the old one.
    9754             :      *
    9755             :      * XXX: Don't do this if the page was restored from full page image. We
    9756             :      * don't bother to update the FSM in that case, it doesn't need to be
    9757             :      * totally accurate anyway.
    9758             :      */
    9759      180216 :     if (newaction == BLK_NEEDS_REDO && !hot_update && freespace < BLCKSZ / 5)
    9760       22414 :         XLogRecordPageWithFreeSpace(rlocator, newblk, freespace);
    9761      180216 : }

    9970             : 
    9971             : void
    9972     3388466 : heap_redo(XLogReaderState *record)
    9973             : {
    9974     3388466 :     uint8       info = XLogRecGetInfo(record) & ~XLR_INFO_MASK;
    9975             : 
    9976             :     /*
    9977             :      * These operations don't overwrite MVCC data so no conflict processing is
    9978             :      * required. The ones in heap2 rmgr do.
    9979             :      */
    9980             : 
    9981     3388466 :     switch (info & XLOG_HEAP_OPMASK)
    9982             :     {
    9983     2522904 :         case XLOG_HEAP_INSERT:
    9984     2522904 :             heap_xlog_insert(record);
    9985     2522904 :             break;
    9986      564150 :         case XLOG_HEAP_DELETE:
    9987      564150 :             heap_xlog_delete(record);
    9988      564150 :             break;
    9989      111442 :         case XLOG_HEAP_UPDATE:
    9990      111442 :             heap_xlog_update(record, false);

   10057             : /*
   10058             :  * Mask a heap page before performing consistency checks on it.
   10059             :  */
   10060             : void
   10061           0 : heap_mask(char *pagedata, BlockNumber blkno)
   10062             : {
   10063           0 :     Page        page = (Page) pagedata;

   10071           0 :     for (off = 1; off <= PageGetMaxOffsetNumber(page); off++)
   10072             :     {
   10073           0 :         ItemId      iid = PageGetItemId(page, off);
   10074             :         char       *page_item;
   10075             : 
   10076           0 :         page_item = (char *) (page + ItemIdGetOffset(iid));
   10077             : 
   10078           0 :         if (ItemIdIsNormal(iid))
   10079             :         {
   10080           0 :             HeapTupleHeader page_htup = (HeapTupleHeader) page_item;
   10081             : 
   10082             :             /*
   10083             :              * If xmin of a tuple is not yet frozen, we should ignore
   10084             :              * differences in hint bits, since they can be set without
   10085             :              * emitting WAL.
   10086             :              */

   10088           0 :                 page_htup->t_infomask &= ~HEAP_XACT_MASK;

   10093           0 :                 page_htup->t_infomask &= ~HEAP_XMAX_COMMITTED;
   10094             :             }
   10095             : 
   10096             :             /*
   10097             :              * During replay, we set Command Id to FirstCommandId. Hence, mask
   10098             :              * it. See heap_xlog_insert() for details.
   10099             :              */
   10100           0 :             page_htup->t_choice.t_heap.t_field3.t_cid = MASK_MARKER;
   10101             : 
   10102             :             /*
   10103             :              * For a speculative tuple, heap_insert() does not set ctid in the
   10104             :              * caller-passed heap tuple itself, leaving the ctid field to
   10105             :              * contain a speculative token value - a per-backend monotonically
   10106             :              * increasing identifier. Besides, it does not WAL-log ctid under
   10107             :              * any circumstances.
   10108             :              *
   10109             :              * During redo, heap_xlog_insert() sets t_ctid to current block
   10110             :              * number and self offset number. It doesn't care about any
   10111             :              * speculative insertions on the primary. Hence, we set t_ctid to
   10112             :              * current block number and self offset number to ignore any
   10113             :              * inconsistency.
   10114             :              */
   10115           0 :             if (HeapTupleHeaderIsSpeculative(page_htup))
   10116           0 :                 ItemPointerSet(&page_htup->t_ctid, blkno, off);
   10117             : 
   10118             :             /*
   10119             :              * NB: Not ignoring ctid changes due to the tuple having moved
   10120             :              * (i.e. HeapTupleHeaderIndicatesMovedPartitions), because that's
   10121             :              * important information that needs to be in-sync between primary
   10122             :              * and standby, and thus is WAL logged.
   10123             :              */
   10124             :         }
   10125             : 
   10126             :         /*
   10127             :          * Ignore any padding bytes after the tuple, when the length of the
   10128             :          * item is not MAXALIGNed.

   10133           0 :             int         padlen = MAXALIGN(len) - len;

   10135           0 :             if (padlen > 0)

   10137             :         }
   10138             :     }
   10139           0 : }
   10140             : 
   10141             : /*
   10142             :  * HeapCheckForSerializableConflictOut
   10143             :  *      We are reading a tuple.  If it's not visible, there may be a
   10144             :  *      rw-conflict out with the inserter.  Otherwise, if it is visible to us
   10145             :  *      but has been deleted, there may be a rw-conflict out with the deleter.
   10146             :  *
   10147             :  * We will determine the top level xid of the writing transaction with which
   10148             :  * we may be in conflict, and ask CheckForSerializableConflictOut() to check
   10149             :  * for overlap with our own transaction.
   10150             :  *
   10151             :  * This function should be called just about anywhere in heapam.c where a
   10152             :  * tuple has been read. The caller must hold at least a shared lock on the
   10153             :  * buffer, because this function might set hint bits on the tuple. There is
   10154             :  * currently no known reason to call this function from an index AM.
   10155             :  */
   10156             : void
   10157   201356740 : HeapCheckForSerializableConflictOut(bool visible, Relation relation,
   10158             :                                     HeapTuple tuple, Buffer buffer,
   10159             :                                     Snapshot snapshot)
   10160             : {
   10161             :     TransactionId xid;
   10162             :     HTSV_Result htsvResult;
   10163             : 
   10164   201356740 :     if (!CheckForSerializableConflictOutNeeded(relation, snapshot))
   10165   201306070 :         return;
   10166             : 
   10167             :     /*
   10168             :      * Check to see whether the tuple has been written to by a concurrent
   10169             :      * transaction, either to create it not visible to us, or to delete it
   10170             :      * while it is visible to us.  The "visible" bool indicates whether the
   10171             :      * tuple is visible to us, while HeapTupleSatisfiesVacuum checks what else
   10172             :      * is going on with it.
   10173             :      *
   10174             :      * In the event of a concurrently inserted tuple that also happens to have
   10175             :      * been concurrently updated (by a separate transaction), the xmin of the
   10176             :      * tuple will be used -- not the updater's xid.
   10177             :      */
   10178       50670 :     htsvResult = HeapTupleSatisfiesVacuum(tuple, TransactionXmin, buffer);
   10179       50670 :     switch (htsvResult)
   10180             :     {
   10181       49066 :         case HEAPTUPLE_LIVE:
   10182       49066 :             if (visible)
   10183       49040 :                 return;
   10184          26 :             xid = HeapTupleHeaderGetXmin(tuple->t_data);
   10185          26 :             break;
   10186         704 :         case HEAPTUPLE_RECENTLY_DEAD:
   10187             :         case HEAPTUPLE_DELETE_IN_PROGRESS:
   10188         704 :             if (visible)
   10189         562 :                 xid = HeapTupleHeaderGetUpdateXid(tuple->t_data);
   10190             :             else
   10191         142 :                 xid = HeapTupleHeaderGetXmin(tuple->t_data);
   10192             : 
   10193         704 :             if (TransactionIdPrecedes(xid, TransactionXmin))
   10194             :             {
   10195             :                 /* This is like the HEAPTUPLE_DEAD case */
   10196         126 :                 Assert(!visible);
   10197         126 :                 return;
   10198             :             }
   10199         578 :             break;
   10200         652 :         case HEAPTUPLE_INSERT_IN_PROGRESS:
   10201         652 :             xid = HeapTupleHeaderGetXmin(tuple->t_data);
   10202         652 :             break;
   10203         248 :         case HEAPTUPLE_DEAD:
   10204         248 :             Assert(!visible);
   10205         248 :             return;
   10206           0 :         default:
   10207             : 
   10208             :             /*
   10209             :              * The only way to get to this default clause is if a new value is
   10210             :              * added to the enum type without adding it to this switch
   10211             :              * statement.  That's a bug, so elog.
   10212             :              */
   10213           0 :             elog(ERROR, "unrecognized return value from HeapTupleSatisfiesVacuum: %u", htsvResult);

   10215             :             /*

   10218             :              * allows xid to be used below without initialization. Silence

   10220             :              */

   10222             :     }

   10227             :     /*
